column8: A Spiritual and Scenic Journey to Mihintale
column11: Visiting Mihintale was an unforgettable experience! The moment you arrive, you‚Äôre greeted by serene surroundings and a sense of history that feels almost tangible. Climbing the steps to the summit was a little challenging, but every step was worth it for the breathtaking views of the surrounding Anuradhapura plains. The ancient Buddhist ruins, including the monasteries, stupas, and the sacred Bodhi tree, reflect the deep spiritual significance of this place. The Mihintale rock carvings and the bell tower are particularly impressive, offering a glimpse into the craftsmanship of ancient Sri Lanka. What I loved most was the peaceful ambiance; it‚Äôs easy to feel a sense of calm and reflection here. Make sure to bring water, wear comfortable shoes, and allocate a few hours to fully explore the site. The sunrise from the top is absolutely magical and worth waking up early for! Highly recommend this spot for history enthusiasts, pilgrims, or anyone looking to experience Sri Lanka‚Äôs cultural heritage. Mihintale is a true gem that combines spirituality, history, and natural beauty.

Lovely place to visit. Try to get there early before the tout groups arrive and the rocks get too hot. You need to take your shoes off before you get to the terrace and the steps are not very smooth. Once on the terrace you can climb a fairly steep rock to a peak with excellent views. The climb is not too strenuous but does require cooperation between ascenders and descenders. It is quite slippery coming down, There is a higher terrace with a couple of huge stupas and also a third climb to the large Buddha statue. Lots of interesting things in addition to these. Be wary of getting food out of your bag - the monkeys will be on you immediately. All in all, well worth a visit.

To do, starting from the point closest to the temple so as to make fewer steps you arrive in an area with a temple surrounded by three hills that lead one to a lookout, one to the Buddha statue and one to the stupa. Be careful because slippery and in the sun burns both the stone and the handrail

Clustered around a hilltop, this Buddhist complex was worth seeing. Its been known that Buddism originated here. The climb requires a visitor to be fit enough to walk up the old stone steps. As this is a sacred place, you must remove your shoes before climbing.

The trip to Mihintale was great! Especially the leadership with Nandana contributed significantly! He took us not only through the temple complex, but also to more remote places we would never have found without him. His facts and stories about history and religion, but also facts about different animals and plants were super interesting. By the way, he supported us in capturing everything photographically. We can highly recommend this tour, and especially the super likable Nandana! A great experience from start to finish!
Mihinthale Anuradapura fast time buddisham came please . You can climb rock and have a step. Easy climp. And very old place

With the group tour and our guide Mihintale visited, Buddhists believe that Buddhism originated here. At the beginning of the climb there are men (locals) who want to accompany you to the top. They walked with us like that, which was actually very nice they offered good help, of course they expect money for that. It is quite a climb, and you have to hold on to the railings at some parts. At the top you have a great view, this staircase is the most difficult of the three. Then you have the stairs to the Stupa and the stairs to Buddha. So it was very busy on Saturday, and shoes off. Watch out for monkeys, there are a lot of them
This was our first stop on our tour and a great intro into the Buddhist culture. The views were excellent, a nice stupa, Buddha statue and elements of the anuradpura kingdom. Very worth the trip

The whole area is definitely worth a trip. However, the last few meters to the top were just for chamois. We (all over 60) had difficulty getting up there the last few meters over practically smooth rock. Down was even more difficult. Only suitable for absolutely kickproof people, it can only be done with bare feet.

Small Buddhist complex where you can visit a large stupa, a Buddha and a comma to see the views. Ticket costs 1,000 rupees. Keep in mind that you have to remove your shoes in the enclosure, so I advise you to wear a pair of socks so you don't burn your feet or step on monkey/bird droppings.

What a fabulous place. Half a day full of history and emotions. A very nice temple well maintained. A guide speaking 4 languages including French, fantastic. He took me off the beaten track. I followed them with my eyes closed and I did Bein.
A must-see sight if you are visiting Anuradhapura. The light is particularly good in the late afternoon. It's not a long walk up. Our PickMe driver was happy to wait for us at no extra cost.

We arranged a tour to visit the religious sites in and around Anuradhapura. "Mihintale" is one of the sites we visited. Mihinthale is a mountain in Sri Lanka near Anuradhapura. Its a pilgrimage site for the Buddhists in Sri Lanka, and worshippers around the world. Let me give a brief description of "Mihintale". It has some some religious monuments, and some ruins. Buddhists visit "Mihintale" during the weekends, during special hoildays, or on full moon poya days. This place is always with visitors, local and foreign. Specially in June, on the full moon poya day we could see many pilgrims visit "Mihintale" to make their pilgrimage, and then proceed towards Anuradhapura. It has a story of Thera Mahinda who came to Sri Lanka and met King Devanampiyatissa, and preached the Buddhist doctrine, as per books written by authors. There are many books written by authors about the historical places in Sri Lanka, including Mihintale, Anuradhapura, Polonnaruwa, and other places etc. In Mihintale we could see a small Dagaba, with some stone pillars, a large Stupa known as the "Maha Seya" and a Buddha Statue on the summit of the Mihintale hill. It takes about 15 to 20 minutes to climb the mountain peak. The best time to climb is early morning, so that you could see the sunrise. or in the late afternoon when the sun is not that hot, and see the sunset. These are the best times to climb, as you may get dehydrated. You are advised to take a bottle of water to refresh yourself. Wear proper clothing, as no body parts be exposed. Photography is allowed, but if you are to photographing for a reason, you will need to take permission from the authorities at the site office.  You are not allowed to take photographs with your back shown to the Statue, Dagaba, or the Stupa. I recommend anyone, local or foreign tourists to visit Mihintale, and experience the climb, view of the landscapes, and the sunrise or the sunset from the peak of Mihintale. Anyone would love and enjoy the fleet of steps that makes you climb to the peak. All are welcome to be at Mihintale and enjoy the experience. Will be back with another historic site sooooon. A splendor one of our favorite visits to Anuradhapura, 1000 Lkr the entrance. A little climber but the place is worth a visit.

We stopped by after sightseeing in Anuradhapura. It's hard to climb barefoot, but there are great views. I was worried if I would be able to climb here first, but it took me about an hour to get up and down all the spots. It looks like a power spot in Sri Lanka. You should definitely bring socks as you climb barefoot.
Well worth a visit, small entrance fee & we hired a local guide which proved invaluable as we wouldn't have seen or done a fraction of the things we did including climbing to the top barefoot.

About 15 mins from the car park to the first stupa flat area.  From there, you have three 10-min further hikes (and 10-min back down) options:  the highest rock point (most popular), the large white budda statue, and the white large stupa.  All are worth it.  Need less than 2 hours to do it all, probably just 1.5 hours.  Great in the evening when cooler and after a day touring the sights of Anuradhapura

We chose to see Mihintale instead of the archaeological part of Anuradhapura both because of cost and because it seemed to us a less dispersive and more enjoyable visit. We did well üôÇ! This place, which has an important significance in the history of Buddhism on the island, is a concentrate of interests; archaeological, religious (the monastery is alive and vibrant), landscape .. and is full of peace. From Anuradhapura the site is easily accessible by bus from the new station in no time and the entrance costs 1500 rupees. Watch out for monkeys who prey on food. Don't miss it!
This place is a very beautiful place to see many things in the world. It is very beautiful to see the sunset and the sunrise in the morning.

Mihintale, located in Sri Lanka, is a significant religious and historical site. It's known as the birthplace of Buddhism in Sri Lanka, with a pilgrimage site atop a hill offering panoramic views. Visitors often appreciate the serene atmosphere, ancient ruins, and the opportunity to learn about Buddhism's introduction to the island. However, the climb to the top can be steep, so it's advisable to wear comfortable shoes and bring water. Overall, it's a culturally enriching experience for those interested in history and spirituality.
Very good tour guide and highly recommend Best photographer I recommend him to definitely choose him if you are going to sri lanka

He is a very good road consultant and showed us very well the places in his area as well as the management needs of his area.  Also, he is a good photographer, so I will name him so that you can also come with him and get his tour.  thank you

Someone needs to remove the ‚Äúnot touristy at all‚Äù refrain from the first few hits this place brings up in google. While not crawling per southeast, it definitely has a good crowd going, for the sunset hike at least. I accepted the services of a guide named Ruan. Guy was a bit annoying at first but ended up giving me such a thorough history lesson and a terrific little hidden sunset spot (better than where the throngs headed), I ended up paying him $20 not just the $10 he‚Äôd originally asked.

We visited this site on our way to ANURADHAPURA, the capital of Sri Lanka for 1000 years. This site dates back to the time of the first king who converted to Buddhism (247 BC): the ruins are scattered across the hillside leading to a large white stupa. On the opposite side there is a large statue of a seated Buddha, and a hilltop with a staircase that is difficult to access. Much visited by faithful until dusk.

Beautiful place, beautiful sunset. Tip if you want to do a tour where you also see the non-touristy spots (which is recommended) book a tour with Amara. Very friendly, not pushy, knows everything and is extremely enthusiastic. Had a very nice day. Phone number: +94760514232

Have it dropped off by a tuk tuk. Just too late for the sunset. Climbed a lot of stairs (you could also start a little higher). Beautiful place with great views. Put on slippers! You have to take off your shoes.
A beautiful place, full of vegetation and nature and a climb along a small path, so to speak. Take care of yourself while you climb......

We went by car from Anuradhapura in the morning, but it was starting to get crowded as our visit in October was during a three day festival, and the day we went the Sri Lankan President was visiting the stupa. We had no trouble buying our tickets.
Beautiful religious place. We went at sunset and found that very nice, just a little less warm, also for your bare feet on those stones. Quite a climb, but so worth it, a truly special place.

Great expectations, but wowww... must do if you visit Sri LANKA. Please we advice you do this with a guide, mister ATHULA he 's amazing. He's knowledge, kindness, tips for beautiful places to make extra ordinary pictures. You can find him at the ticket service. Or by what's app: + 94 72 406 7795 A friend for life...he's wisdom and frienship makes this trip an extra dimensional high level. Family Beerens from Belgium

We hired a tuk-tuk in Anuradhapura to take us to Mihinthale one morning.  There was a ceremony taking place when we arrived and it was really lovely to watch.  Such a peaceful place.  Fewer tourists than at Anuradhapura sites.

Mihinthale is a must-visit for anyone traveling to Anuradhapura. This beautiful and serene site is considered one of the most important pilgrimage sites in Buddhism, and it's easy to see why. The views from the top of the hill are breathtaking, and the many ancient ruins and temples are a testament to the rich history and cultural heritage of Sri Lanka. There are limited options for food and drinks, and restrooms may not be as modern or well-maintained as visitors might expect. These are the negative facts in Mihinthale. So, I cannot give the full rate.

We visited Mihintale with a really great tour guide, he was super friendly and showed us all over the mountain and had so much knowledge about the monks who occupied the area and  how they lived. We arrived at 3ish and arrived at the top to watch the sunset. Highly recommend using O.V.Athulawansa, you can contact him via WhatsApp +94 72 406 7795

If you visit the ancient capitals of Sri Lanka, this is a must visit. Take time to climb up and explore the grounds and the temples and the very windy rock right on top. The best time to go is the afternoon since you need to go bear feet for part of the distance. The magically lit up Anuradhapura can be seen when descending offering many photo ops.
Must visited place in Sri Lanka. Spectacular view and much more to explore. Ancient caves and stupas are interesting things to do.

Just 13km east of Anuradhapura is Mihintale, the place where Buddhism was introduced to Sri Lanka . The story goes that Mahinda, a Buddhist missionary from India (and the son of the great Buddhist Emperor, Ahsoka), had a chance meeting with the Sinhalese King, Devanampiya Tissa, who was out hunting in the hills and promptly converted the king and all of his entourage.
It was so peaceful and nice there. One of the best places I‚Äôve visited in Sri Lanka. Would definitely recommend it!

It can get very crowded so you might not be able to stand on the small summit. Still, there are other places to go for a view. If you want to see the Buddha in sunlight go at sunset. For the stupa visit at sunrise. Tip - take a pair of socks since it‚Äôs no shoes for the upper part of the climb.

Beautiful place, located on a little hill. For sunset you'll have a stunning view and a nice calm atmosphere. It is a bit pricey to go inside is you are a tourist. The stupa and Buddha Statue looks nice in the evening light. I really enjoyed our visit. It was quite empty except for a few monks, local devotees and some few tourist so maybe that added to the good experience.

One of buddhists' most sacred places in Sri Lanka. You can have an amazing view from the top of the rock. Its a little bit harder to climb the rock I in sunny afternoons. So mornings and evenings are better to visit here.
We went to the top of the rock in a Saturday morning. Try to go there around 6.00 am before crowd gather around the place..

Important religious site in Sri Lanka. However, even if you are not religious well worth a visit to take in the spectacular views back to the ancient city of Anuradhapura and also to Ritigala. In fact you have 360 degree views from the Stupa and even better from the top of the rock. The latter is quiet tricky to climb even when there are no people around, but yourselves. Entrance fee LKR1000. Approximately 30-45 minute drive from Anuradhapura, but well worth it.
The place where king Devanampiyathissa met Mihindu thero at ancient Sri Lanka where the new era begins with buddha sasana.
Plan your visit early hours in the morning or late afternoon. Be prepared to navigate 400 to 700 plus stone steps.
Very beautiful Budhist Temple. This is the place where Mihidu Himi met Sinhala king Thissa. One of significant place of Buddhism history
Food was fantastic . Close to town. Beautiful  garden . Friendly And helpfull staff. Service good . Big parking space

Oldest sthupa in the world and it's just 5.2 kms away from waterfront home stay in anuradhapura. It has a large number of relics inside. Built in 242 BC by King dutu gamunu after defeating the then ruler "elara".first anuradhapura known as "anuradha grama "later became anuradha nagara, and now called as anuradhapura.
A wonderful site, but be prepared for walking over a huge area without shoes and some areas are rough underfoot.  Stones very hot to walk on, so take some old socks to wear.

It was a hot day but the place was empty. We had been told it was best to wear socks when climbing the rock due to the heat. What they don't tell you is that the hand rail gets cooking hot as well! Take two pairs of socks, one for your feet and the other for your hands. You will thank me if it's a hot day.
This site is well worth the walk up. There is a "hard" climb to the top of the rock but worth it. All the other places of interest at the site are easier. Well worth a visit.

This cultural site holds significant Buddhism history in Sri Lanka. It is a Buddhism Pilgrimage site where is believed that Buddhist monks met up with the King as far back as 300BC and the Buddhism was inaugurated in Sri Lanka. Foreigners fee of LKR1,000 per person per entry. It took us about 30 mins to walk up the staircase to the site with some notable ruins. There are 3 other sites which include the access to the massive white stupa, a massive Buddha statue and clim-up to the top of the rock which provides stunning panoramic views. The climb up to the rock is not so straight forward for people afraid of height since it is not easy to climb up bare footed even most of the path is built with railing as some part are quite steep and much precaution is required. Proper dressing is necessary to cover shoulder and pants/ dress below knee with no shoes allowed at the site. It is easier to visit during morning or late afternoon when the ground is not too hot for the bare foot walking. Recommended for anyone into cultural/ historical sites in Anuradhapura.
Good spot to visit at sunset. The view from the stupa is lovely. There is also a second lookout and a giant Buddha to see.

For the well travelled this was a little disappointing - you've seen one large white stupa before so not too impressed.  The old city ruins are also very sparse and not much to see.  Was a fairly easy climb up all the steps but wear socks if you can rather than going barefoot.  The reclining Buddha inside is nice but not stunning.  There is a mini stupa at the bottom to look at rather than do the steps.  If you have time go, if pushed for time then there are more worthy things to go visit, I think.

there is an ancient hospital here, a small museum, and a few monastery compounds (if I remember correctly), and then there is Kaludiya pond which is a beautiful place to relax and enjoy nature (there are also ancient structures here too).

Great experience. Lots of history to explore as well as climbing up to the temple area which is still a holy site for Buddhists today.  Nice to see active pilgrims still enjoying this famous and historical site for family devotions and enjoyable days out Make sure you explore the whole site and don‚Äôt just visit the top temple part The ancient hospital is fascinating. Don‚Äôt miss the medication bath by the entrance

East of Anuradhapura, this fabled site was where Mahinda, a relative of Ashoka, the Buddhist ruler of India, met the local king Devanampiya Tissa in 247 BC. After the latter successfully answered the riddle of the mangoes, Mahinda provided teachings of the Buddha. The setting is rugged, quite apart from the 1,850 possible steps to be climbed to see everything. The upper terrace has the most important areas associated with the site, a small dagoba or stupa marking the spot of the meeting. The higher up Mahaseya Dagoba reputedly holds a single hair of the Buddha. There are great views from this level and also the Aradhana Gala, a rock face with iron railings, the location of Mahinda‚Äôs first sermon. The upper terrace needs to be done barefoot and without a hat. It will be worth your while.

My wife and I expected to appreciate Mihintale more than Anuradhapura, which was not the case. The big Buddha statue was nice, but at least for me, the large white statues are not as interesting as many others. The walk up is not big deal, provide you wear socks. We probably spent 1 1/2 hours there, which came as a surprise. Based on online reviews, I thought we would need ch more time. We were both a bit disappointed.

Yes, historic (where Buddhism has first established in Sri Lanka) but there is not much to see. Nice views from the modern Buddha statue, from the main stupa, and from The Rock, but be prepared for much uneven climbing (especially to The Rock) in bare feet. Now, The Rock is where a monk first called upon the deity when Buddhism became established in the country, but it‚Äôs just a big rock on an uneven, steep rock outcrop. If that excites you, great. Really a bit underwhelming, though the historical importance cannot be denied. No fun in bad weather.

After a wonderful experience at Sri Maha Bodhi, we arrived in Mihintale to walk around the stupa. We walked up to the second landing, where we were accosted by the rudest people we have ever come across. After accusing us of not paying the entrance fee, we walked over to a hidden demountable ticket office to pay the fee. However, when we were vilified for being white, we decided not to stay. There is no fee for non-white people at this place and the touts are extraordinarily rude. However, if our driver had warned us about the wannabe guides, we may not have had these problems.

We have been to Mihintale in a evening around 4 pm, we believe it is the great time to climb the rock, not too hot and nice wind blowing through you. Absolutely amazing view from the top. Also the feeling you get around is so spiritual. Mihintale is about 13Km far from the city. But do not miss this place if you are panning your trip to Anuradhapura.
Lovely look around the old city easy to drive around. Great ruins and amazing rock to climb up very steep.

Our main worry was the climb, we were daunted by talk of the 1800 steps and how steep it is. But if you take a tuktuk up to start from  from the midway point rather than the bottom, it is totally fine, the remaining bit is easy, less than a half hour to the top. And the top is spectacular. It‚Äôs a complex of three little hills with the Buddhist sites, each with an amazing view in each direction, including a great sunset over Anuradhapura
What a beatiful temple after a bit of climbing. I feel all of the spirit in my brain and heart. Greeneries,views was awesome , ƒ±t worths to climb without shoes

Easy to navigate. We went here very early in the morning from Colombo. We arrived at 3am and were not allowed yet to go up so we went back at 5am. Sunrise view is amazing. We spent more than an hour just appreciating the views.
Superb ambience all around, with Lord Buddha gracing the place with his presence everywhere. Serene, beautiful.
Easy to navigate the vast site, the temples themselves are not that impressive the panorama is - the rock is fun although tedious to climb, the best being the remote summit
Very nice view, especialy during sunrise and sunset. We like this place more then Anuradhapura. Usual tuk-tuk price from Anuradhapura - 1.500LKR

Two uncles at the shoe-keeping area had noticed that my sandals were spoilt though I merely left them at the shoe rack, and when I headed down, I saw they were trying their best to fix it (it is hard, as I'd tried for myself..) . SUPER THANKFUL FOR THE LOVELY TOUCH and this was the most heartening part of my whole trip. :)))) Bless and lots of gratitude for you guys! Location: Superb view at the highest point, do climb up the place where there hoardings for you to hold, it is very worth it. Beware of monkeys ;)
We did this with Sweet Home Special Tour. It was amazing. And we were able to visit some hidden places there.
Nice to visit because close to Anuradhapura but I would not go out of my way to visit here. Nice view from the top though

This place has been associated with the earliest introduction to Buddhism in Sri Lanka. There is a small ceremony at 18:00 every evening. A few monks walk from the monastery up to the white stupa carrying offerings and drumming. It‚Äôs best to already be at the top of the stupa before it starts. If you go here with a driver, ask them to stop at Mihidu Aranya. It‚Äôs close to the Mihintale site. It‚Äôs the one of most impressive trees you will ever see. Monks use it for prayer.
Nice historical place. Buddhist. Good view. First Buddhist place after came to philosophy to Sri Lanka.

According to legend, it was at Mihintale ‚Äì literally ‚ÄúMahinda‚Äôs Hill‚Äù ‚Äì that the Indian missionary Mahinda, met and converted King Devanampiyatissa in 247 BC, establishing Buddhism as the island‚Äôs state religion. Mahinda was the son of the great Mauryan emperor Asoka, sent by his father to bring word of the Buddha‚Äôs teachings to Sri Lanka. Buddhism was immediately embraced with fervour by the Sinhalese people and soon became firmly established in the island ‚Äì unlike in India, its birthplace, where it would subsequently fall into terminal decline. Mihintale, on a higher plane All over the world, high places are given religious significance, with the result that devotees are always climbing steps. Sometimes on their knees. Mihintale is one such place, its various shrines connected by a total of some 1,840 steps that ultimately lead to the summit ‚Äì steep enough to require deep breaths and a meditative pace. They were built in the reign of Bhathika Abhaya (22 BC‚ÄìAD 7), although a later paved road provides a short cut up to the first level.there have so many histrionically place in here

A must do if you are in the area, quite the climb but should pose no issue if you are willing to make an effort. Would recommend this site to all people who are even remotely interested in culture and/or nature. The view is absolutely stunning!

Yesterday we did a tour at Mihintale. We met an amazing guide. His name is Nandana Weerasiri. He is an experienced guide with a lot of knowledge about buddihsm, Mihintale and it's surroundings. He speaks multiple languages (fluently englisch and french). He showed us the beautifull sights of Mihintale and it's surroundings. In the evening we saw the sunset at the big dagoba at a private spot. Yesterday he showed us an ancient tree, bridge, the black lake pond and after a big climb we had a stunning view of all the historic temples and places we had seen during the day. Nandana even arranged a place where we could leave our backpacks during the tour. He is very happy to show you around at all this beautifull places. For contact his phone number is:  0772311254

It was a pretty good experience learning the history behind the area and I have to say if you plan on going here make sure to have the necessary items for you to Hydrate as you can easily dehydrate due to the hot weather and climate.
Beautiful historical site, where Buddhism was first introduced to Sri Lanka. The site is very popular with the locals, which really makes you appreciate the importance of the place. Don't miss it.
Mihintale is not only a historical site to visit this a place where you can watch birds .try it out early in the morning you will enjoy that experience for sure

We have two kids - 10 and 6. And wanted to take them to Mihintale to show all the ruins. We found the places to be beautiful, much less crowded than Anuradhapura and Polonnaruwa, and having good access and average walking/ climbing time. Must visit places are Mihintale Temple, Buddha statue, Cela Chaityaya and Aradhana Gal. Also make a note to visit Kaludiya Pokuna.
We started our visit on the Mihintale sagred hill which has a big Buddha statue, hill to climb to admire the views and a stupa, an incredible visit.

We visited Mihintale late in the afternoon on a Saturday. Wasn‚Äôt overly crowded but plenty of locals making pilgrimage up the hill. 1,840+ steps to the top, mostly shaded by huge trees. But you can also cheat if you have a driver they can drive you halfway. There are 3 peaks to ascend - a giant Buddha, a stupa and a lookout rock. Very windy up top. No shoes allowed. Well worth the views.
Beautiful place to visit. Stunning setting, with breathtaking views from the top of the hill. Highly recommend!

I had heard of this place but hadn‚Äòt really looked into it. So we hadn‚Äòt really planned on going here. It was only because our tuk-tuk driver, who had taken us to the old town in Anuradhapur, had suggested us to go here that we went in the evening. In the end, we were very glad that we went there. The sunset was beautiful and we liked it even more than the old town. Before the sunset, we also took a guide on the spot. His English was very good and he explained a lot but didn‚Äòt overdo it.

This temple complex contains several important things which have a strong religious importance. Maybe the most important one is the Mihintale Rock. Actually, it's not easy to climb (especially without shoes). I made the first series of steps but then I gave up because I considered it quite dangerous, the rock is quite slippery. Anyway, I did some tours around it.

We visited this area at 4:30 pm and found lots of posted information, describing what we were looking at.  There were also 3 big climbs - up to the Buddha, up the rock and up to the Stupa.  The views were spectacular.  We did the Stupa last and sat and watched the sunset.
Head up in the afternoon to skip the heat but allow time to climb each of the three sites and end on one ready to watch a spectacular sunset.  Climbing looks. Much harder than it is. Give it a go!!
do it soon. Sri Lanka has undergone some recent disruptions but truely it is  safe , friendly & a great place to see. The place relies on tourism & it is hurting.

Our visit here was worth it as from the car park we came across the ruins of a hospital and on entering there was a stone with the interior carved in a human form. Nearby is a museum with archaeological finds.

This temple is quite small with elements rather spread out.  It is located on a hill, so expect to climb lots of steps.  The views are excellent.  The topmost sections are sacred, so you need to climb barefoot
Loved it. It is a climb but should not be missed. Very good views. Be careful to go at the top of the rock as you bear foot.

We were there two days ago. Not very crowded (not sure is it because of the recent bombing incidents). Entrance fee 500 rupees each and we spend about 2 hours here. Nice temple with great surroundings

We visited Mihintale for a couple of hours while travelling between Anuradhapura and Sigiriya and it was well worth the stop. We picked up a guide at the entrance which made the whole experience all the better as he described the history and relevance of the site and showed us some spots we may otherwise have missed. Shoes have to be left before enterning the main site so take socks to avoid the grit and the heat. There are four main components to the complex at Mihintale and three require climbing up steps/rocks so it's not a good option for anyone with impaired mobility.  The centrepiece in Mihintale is the Ambasthale Dagoba which is where a former King is said to have converted to buddhism. Up some steps to  one side of the main Dagoba is a relatively new white statue of buddha which looks great against the blue sky. On another side is the large Mahaseya Dagoba which offers good views across the area. We visited when it was offering time so were treated to a bit of ceremony. Then there is a tricky rock to climb (especially if you are wearing socks as it can be a bit slippy so think about taking them off briefly) which gives wonderful 360 views of the site and surrounding area, all the way back to Anuradhapura, where you can see varous dagobas in the skyline. On the way back down we stopped at Sinha Pokuna to see the lion carving. Its a wonderful and fascinating site and would be a great place to be for sunrise or sunset

This smaller site is cheaper and better maintained than the whole of Anuradhapura.  Nice views, but since you have to remove your shoes, some of the steps can be slippery in socks.  Watch out for aggressive monkeys too!

I enjoyed my visit to Mihintale and it is a great half-day trip while in Anuradhapura.  It is very interesting, and everything can be visited in about 2-3 hours.  Note that as all sacred placed in Sri Lanka, you will need to walk around without shoes, so try to take a pair of thick socks to make your visit more comfortable.  Also, try to avoid going in the middle of the day as it gets extremely hot.  Even the rails to go up/down the rock can get very hot at times, so a pair of gloves would not be a bad idea. The views from the rock are great!!!

Came here for sunset, climbed the steps to the temple and the rock to watch the sunset. Such a beautiful view. There are a lot of monkeys!! One followed me for a while as he saw I had peanuts and he stole them from my bag haha! Enjoy, being modest clothing as it‚Äôs a temple.

The stair case to the top of the rock is steep and cut into the rock. I recommend this place for the younger crowd and those who are fit. The view from the top is awesome. Mostly visited by local buddhists and foreign vistors.

Travelled by lots of Sri Lankans and Foreigners!. We are grateful to our guide Sunil at TourMart.lk for introducing this place while visiting Anuradhapura. He gave us a very good explanation about the history of Mihintale.

Group visit. Steep climb to Invitation Rock for the panoramic views. All the more awkward with no footwear or headgear allowed in the very hot sun. Then climb again to the Stupa. A fascinating site, but difficult for those not very able.
Use a Tuk Tuk to get half way up so it‚Äôs less painful to climb and arrive by 06.00 to be sure of the sunrise. Absolutely do it for sunrise! Cool  temperatures and few tourists.

We left our hotel in Anuradhapura at 3.30 pm for the trip to Mihintale to get there for 4 ish to make sure we got to summit for sunset. Lots of steps but our tuk tuk driver took us to the car park entrance half way up to save our legs. Great views although clouded over a little at sunset. Beware the monkeys as they steal from any bags left open

We climbed "Mihintale Mountain" where Buddhism arrived in Sri Lanka.  The climb on a hot mid-day was up a very irregular set of steps in the stone with some bars on the side.  We did get a view at the top.  We did not climb to the top of the other temple.  Again, we had to remove our shoes and wore our temple sox.

After a hot and discouraging day at Anuradhapura, with no maps available, very few helpful signs, and staff that couldn't direct us anywhere, we were glad to take a tuk-tuk to Minintale the following day. Much of the walkways are shaded, and the lushness of the setting is more welcoming.  We picked up a stronger sense of the past, of the island's Buddhist heritage as we explored without a guide. Take the time to wander off on side paths, away from the throngs along the 1,800 steps.  There's refrigerated bottled water available for sale at the top.

This is a much better place to visit than the Anuradhapura Archaeological Park and for a fraction of the entry fee - 500 rupees!! Mihintale is easily reached by bus from Anuradhapura new town bus station, it takes about half an hour and costs 40 rupees. From the bus stop it‚Äôs a walk of about 400 metres to the museum which makes for an interesting stop before entering the park itself. Just past the museum you climb a long stone staircase to a landing area where the ticket office is. From this area further sets of stairs lead to the various sites (it has to be said there are lots  of stairs to climb to cover this site properly but if you take it easy it shouldn‚Äôt cause a problem). The main route takes you up to the core area of the site where you find the Ambasthale Dagoba, a large seated buddha statue and a rocky viewpoint. The area is peaceful and scenic and the views from the upper levels are stunning. A less travelled set of stairs from the area around the ticket office takes you to the ruined stupa of Et Vihara. We went later in the day and it was perfect timing.  Got to see a spectacular sunset and the views were spectacular as well.  Didn't find it to touristy.

1400 stairs require some efforts to get there but the place is unbelievable! The best option is to go there early in the morning (7-8 am), then you have a chance to enjoy the place with less tourists and it gives incredible feelings!

When you look at this site, you think that it looks impressive down here.  It is worth climbing up and seeing for yourself.  The views are stunning.  I dont like heights but i was determined to do it.  The fact that you cannot wear shoes here actually makes climbing easier, but the rocks do get a bit hot!! You just have to wonder, how they managed to built such impressive temples.

Quite a marvelous historic spot. The lore says Buddhism was created in Sri Lanka here. The place is historic and impressive. Terrific views. Mihintale is located in Anuradhapura district in the cultural triangle of Sri Lanka. This place is a must if you are interested in knowing the history of Sri Lanka as well as visit the sites related to Sri Lankan history.

Visited here and Anuradhapura on the same day and really enjoyed both places. You have quite a few steps to climb coming from the car park and then when you get there it is shoes off, so it is worth wearing some thick socks as the ground can get quite hot and it can be rough in some places. We opted to this off the beaten path visit to Mihintale which turned out to be a great experience. It is smaller and less crowded by tourists as opposed to the main sights in Anuradhapura. We were lucky enough to find a wonderful local guide to take us around - very knowledgeable and great spirited. His name is Athula Wansa and he can be reached by phone at +94-76-693-8585
This ancient site is fascinating, but you do need a guide to get the most from it.  Fabulous views. The monastery site is huge.

Mihintale is a favourite place in the whole of the island.  The modest effort required to climb to the dagoba is amply rewarded with marvellously extensive views all around, of wewas and jungle.  This is a historic place and has a spiritual feel about that one finds rarely, even in Sri Lanka.  There are several monuments on the way and the hike can be extended in two directions, given that you have suitable footwear, not deposited as required on the way.
Chose to have a guide which was worthwhile, he gave insight into the site and Buddhism in Sri Lanka.  Nice combination of manmade features and rock formations.  Nice view.

A nice and impressive historical place.More than 2000 years ago the place was developed by ancient kings. Steps made by stones, so many steps, has to be careful and take a rest in the middle.We watched the sunset and it was amazing. The "Dagaba" in the top of the mountain and the surrounding view were amazing. Worth climbing.

Climbed all the way up. Quite a demand on the knees but the views at the top were worth it. Enjoyed reading about various sites/ ruins on the way. Recommended. One minor gripe - large square at top to be crossed with no shoes (understandably) but the surface in certain areas was quite harsh!

Mihintale is a really interesting site and despite being listed under Anuradhaura on TA it is in fact 12 km away in the village of Mihintale.  Contrary to some advice tickets were not at the museum, which is small and not too interesting and you can miss, they were at the upper level car park. This is back to the road and then second left after the museum and gets you three quarters of the way up. The stupa was impressive on top of one hill, a reconstruction not original, a Buddha statue on another hill, the pilgrimage hill a third point all off a central area with another stupa in the centre. I saw morning sun rise and evening sunset. Very ancient place. Lot of hills with dagabos and steps made out of stone  with nice views.

Wonderful views from the top and, if you are not a climber, a driver can go up a good part of the way. You have to climb without a hat or shoes the last bit as it is a holy site, but there are railings.

I didn't put five stars because it poured while I was visiting, so my visibility was greatly reduced; I didn't get to see some of the views over the area. You get to climb a lot of stairs to see this sight. It's pretty impressive, knowing that devotees climb all the stairs regularly.

Cycled from Anuradhapura (12km) to visit this temple that sits ontop of more steps. There is a climb up to a prayer rock with the most stunning views however its not for the faint hearted...the steps are in fact grooves into rocks. My advice is to take off your socks for extra grip!!

Simply excellent spot for sunset. Go for dagoba 40 min before sunset, then move to Buddha statue and find secret spot (a trail behind left back side of Buddha). Some nice workout too due intensive steps.

We drove to the parking halfway up, then there are a few stairs until you are in the main complex. A few miles from Anuradaphura lies this amazing viewpoint atop a small mountain.  You can take a vehicle most of the way up to a parking area and explore from there--a rock viewpoint, stupa, and Buddha statue..... or just find some shade and enjoy some quiet time.

the temple complex of Mihintale is worth the visit; nice hill to climb for a spectacular view over the surrounding area, as well interesting in terms of historical heritage. nice to spend couple of hours around it
Mihinthatale is one of amazing  view point .worth to visit in the morning or evening ,it is a most important place for Buddhist ,

We stopped in unplanned while on a cycle tour and really enjoyed this site at dusk / sunset. A very significant and unique combination of archeological site and a site of active Buddhist worship. Very very sacred place Buddhists. Nice place in the old place [Now ruins] but the one big Buddha statue, one big Stupa and one small hill are main attractions there. Mihintale Historical City is a location of my historical researches and to get knowledge about ancient technology I have visited The Hospital, Kantaka Cetiya, The Refectory, Mihintale Slab Inscriptions, Ambasthala Dagaba, The Cave of Arahat Mahinda, Maha Stupa, Aradhana Gala, Kaludiya Pokuna, Naga Pokuna, Singha Pokuna and hope others also happy to visit and knowledge.

Here is the origin of Buddhism in Sri Lanka and what an inspiring place it is. Be ready to make a difficult climb up rough stone steps. Be ready for a sense of peace and serenity. Be ready for stunning vistas and Anuradhapura in the distance.

This is a very interesting site.  As with all temples you need to remove your shoes and cover shoulders and knees.  The climb to the top of the rock is difficult as poeple are travelling in both directions but totally worth it for the awesome views.

This is one of the must visit places in Anuradhapura. Recomend to visit in the eving to view the nice sunset. Lots of steps to climb. BUt really nice view on the top. You can view buitiful dagobas and water tanks.
This is a famous and popular Buddhist temple here. You have to climb the rock.The view from the top is beautiful.
The climb was a small adventure but absolutely worth it. The view is breathtakingly beautiful. A must visit!

We visited at 6 PM around sunset. Parked our car the second level which means about 300 easy stairs to the top. It is Well illuminated at night and the statue floor Buddha was fantastic. Visited here as part of our tour of Sri Lanka and loved it. Just be aware that there is a lot of climbing and most of it has to be done without shoes. Much better than the nearby Anuradhapura. A large amount of temples of different ages concentrated in a relatively small mountain. this is one  of the greatest historic place has many relics, chethiyas, have to walk about thousand of steps, still most of everyone is able to go, better to keep water and beaware of monkeys, dont forget to climb the mihinthala rock and also to clim other  two hills,,
Our hotel recommend us to go in the afternoon to see the sunset, they were completely right :) it was amazing! Just make sure to eat before you go or the monkeys will try to steal your food!

Mihintale was one of our favourite places in Sri Lanka. Best place in anuradhapura. Especially in sunset. You can easily go by tuktuk. Try to climb to the top of the rock.
The mountain is really nice to visit during sunset. There is a ceremony and you can climb to a high point and see very far.

Although you really have to be careful for naughty monkeys this place is definitely worth the visit. After a small stairs climb you will benefit from an amazing view and a beautiful Buddha and temple. Not many tourists at this hidden gem !

We chose Mihintale as it looked more manageable that the much bigger Anuradhapura complex.  Worth taking a guide, who may charge you a bit more than the guide books suggest, but still worth it we found, plus you will see the whole place, not just the obvious bits, and understand it more fully. It is a must see When you reach go right opposite the ticket counter You will climb to the the highest point overlooking the stupa which is much better that climbing the rock You will have a 360 view and the climbing is very scenic

Our homestay organised a trip here for us and we loved our experience here. This was one of our favourite places to visit while we were in Anuradhaphura.
Explained us couple of place in detail with the pagoda and the main shrine where the sacred Mahinda relics were stuffed in a miniature rock Stupa.

Everyone is going for sunset.  So, if you like the crowd it is the best time to go.  If you go a little earlier, you won't have the crowd, it won't be so hot like mid day and still you'll have beautiful pictures and views.  The walk up the rock is not that easy.  A little slippery (way down worse) and no hight fear allowed...
It was a challenging to get up and down from this mountain but definitely worth it. Best way to climb is with barefoot. Must safer then footwear unless you  have sweaty feet üòÜ
In the heat it is a climb to make it to the top of the mountain, but what you will see is totally worth it.

We absolutely loved our visit to Mihintale, even with the bad weather. The stupa is the prettiest one I have seen in Sri Lanka so far. We also loved taking pictures of local wildlife and the vast area we could look at. Definately go if you're nearby.

Spent a lovely couple of hours here. Go at sunrise or sunset. Great views from the large stupor and Buddha. We didn‚Äôt as we‚Äôre both not great with heights but if you are, climb the main rock for spectacular views (we‚Äôve seen photos). A surprisingly picturesque little spot. Well worth an early morning or evening visit. Google for photos, mine are on my main camera.

We went there on normal day.there was no soo much people .actually it is not difficult to climb it also adults.you can see lot of plces there.very nice top of rocak and near the pagoda...very nice place.
Get there in the morning as early as you can, but the silence of the place, the view on the top and the atmosphere are worth climbing up the last rock.
Worth the climb to see the amazing view. Very quite and good exercise. Hired a tuk tuk to get there.

This is a sacred site so you have to remove your shoes before entering. There are a lot of steps and a steep narrow pathway with a handrail to climb the rock--with bare feet! Very hot and windy up there but a super view of the whole site.

This was the pick around this area. Burned off some calories after too many curries! Lol! A nice walk up steps and a cool walk up the rock which my 11 year old enjoyed and did not fret too much about. If you are stupored out come for a look here!
It's bit slippery on the rock on top and windy also it's hot out there in a sunny day. Very small pathway to climb the rock

A beautiful place with a lot of history. I would recommend to all people to take a guide who will tell you all about the history and the Buddhist religion. Super interesting and really ads up to your visit here. If you come across Nananda go with him, he is super kind and will give you amazing background stories.
One of the most sacred places in Sri Lanka. Definitely want to go again and worship this sacred place.

Mihintale is the place where it all started for srilanka , legend has it that at this very spot Mahinda , son of emperor ashoka preached to the king about buddhism , the place itself is serene and calm , very well maintained , from the car park its about 500 mts walk to the bottom of the great stairs , the stair case is wide and dotted with trees , very charming climb if there is one , be sure to wear comfortable walking shoes and light cotton clothes , the entry ticket for non sri lankans is about 1000 LKR , once at the top there are different stupas and a giant buddha statue , and a observation point , the main stupa requires further climb which is bit tricky , a guide is advisable and is available near ticket counter , also there is a museum and relic temple , the entire visit may last upto 3/4 hours

Must visit place, you need not be a religious or history lover, if you like nature and culture then you would enjoy this place. Try to take a guide with you to tell you he story. Better visit it in late afternoon, so that you can watch the sunset from he mountain top. You must climb all the tops, its worth the climb. The view is magnificent from the top.
Stairs to steep for this 71yr old to climb but grand daughter was fine. Very interesting and historic ,worth the effort

Unless you want to prove something to yourself, there is no need to climb all 1800+ steps. Ask your driver to take you up Old Road, which gets you almost halfway up. That leaves only a few hundred steps to climb. Bring water. The ruins at the level of the ticket booth (at the end of Old Road, halfway up the hill) are good for a 15-minute walk-around. The stone canoe at the ‚Äúalms house‚Äù is quite impressive. Apparently, lay people would fill this with rice as donation to the monks who lived here. Don‚Äôt miss the lion carved into the side of Lion Rock. Up the hill, there are three peaks forming a triangle around a basin. The basin is not large -- little bigger than a football field. The lowest peak has an imposing modern statue of the Buddha ‚Äì very easy climb, but not much by way of views from there. The second peak has a huge white stupa; good views from there, especially of the other peaks. The tallest is a steep climb up bare rock (steps cut into the rock with handrails). Great views, but dangerously slippery if wet. Because it‚Äôs a sacred place, you have to take off your shoes as you approach the three peaks and basin. Wear old socks if you‚Äôre not accustomed to walking on paving stones or sand that is frying-pan hot from the tropical sun. Even if not hot, the sharp grit underfoot makes it painful. Th historical significance of this place has to do with being where a king first accepted Buddhism. Entry was 500 rupees. The site does not seem to have any cafe, toilet or shop selling water -- but then again, I didn't look that carefully. Covering the upper steps and peaks leisurely takes only about 90 minutes. To escape the worst of midday sun, you can start the climb at 4pm and still have plenty of light when you reach the top. But there are plenty of shrine-caves and ruins in the area. If you are intent on visiting them, I think you will need an hour or two more, which means starting much earlier than 4pm. I didn‚Äôt bother, as by this point in my visit to the country, I‚Äôve had my fill of Buddhist places. My hotel arranged a tuktuk from Anuradhapura for 4 hours at a cost of 2,000 rupees (leaving little time for shrine-caves). It‚Äôs only 13km or 30 minutes journey time. The driver took me to a few other places before reaching the Mihintale peaks. One was a ‚Äúbig tree‚Äù monastery (nothing much to see except a big tree and a human skeleton); another was the site of a ‚Äúhospital‚Äù dated to about 800 CE (OK for a 10-minute walk-around); and the third was ‚ÄúBlack Water Pool‚Äù (more ruins, so-so views). If your hotel does not offer such a service, it‚Äôs still very easy to hire a tutktuk from anywhere in Anuradhapura for 3 to 4 hours for a similar price.

There is a lovely amount of variation here.¬† It's the monkeys, the giant squirrel.¬† It's the steps, then a flat then more steps then flat then steps carved into rock then 360 views from the highest point.¬† It's the learning when and where is holy ground with shoes on or off.¬† ¬†It's the ledge with superb views (no need to sit on the edge my 14 year old son - no seriously!!)¬† It's learning that Stupas are so large that you can easily lose sight of those you are with and go round in circles for a little longer than necessary.¬† And then there is a word that escapes me to describe the whitest of white for that magnificent Buddha and Stupa here.

A really lovely place to visit. Don‚Äôt be put off by the number of steps, you go up and down so you have respite in between the climbs! I was wondering why it is not more popular ... I spent a peaceful couple of hours exploring here. Well worth it. The entry fee is only 500rupees and so you can afford a guide for a quality experience :)

This is a tough climb in the heat, especially if like me you are in your sixties with dodgy knees. However, if you pace yourself it can be done & the view from the top is great. If possible try & do it early morning before the rock & hand rails heat up.
Mihintalaya is a very historical and religious place that is place Arahath Mahinda tera introduce buddisam to kavanthissa king. Mihintalaya known as Abastala suthupa.
Went here during a local Bank Holiday so there were lots of people paying homage. Not sure that traditional custom of removing foot wear before entering site is appropriate nowadays.

This is a temple near the Anaradhapura complex.  But there is no temple to speak but an open holy site for praying. With a Bodi tree on its grounds. There is a large Stupa,ruins of a refectory , and a large Bodi tree. Really not much to see once you get up there.   The climb up is quite a bit. About 1800 steps but on a gentle gradient. ( for your info, the donations to the shoe keeper is used to fund the running and maintenance of the site). unless you  have  lots of time , its a place which could be missed out.

We visited here as a trip for a few hours from Anuradhapura to see the sunset. We stopped at the ruins of the hospital, the black lake and went up to the stupor and Buddha at the top of the hill. Everything was very beautiful, including the view from the stupor. There was an entrance fee of 500 rupees for the top sector (the stupor etc) and in this area you can't wear shoes. Unfortunately a thunder storm started as soon as we reached the top....but goof fun running down in the warm rain.

It's a buddhist holy place, which you have to visit bare foot.  But the impression is special.  Starting down the hill and climbing the stairs to the upper dagoba brings you in a serene atmosphere. Climbing the rock nearby gives you a beautiful view on the surrounding landscape.

Would recommend for sunset: allowing time to walk to summit and explore. Good idea to pack socks to wear after taking off shoes, as the ground is hot underfoot. No vendors around so be mindful to dress appropriately and pack water. Shoe storage often incurs a fee for western tourists.

It is the birthplace of Buddhism in Sri Lanka where a king Tissa was stopped by a Mihidhu Rahathananwahanse and preached to him not to kill the deer.  Don't let the 1850 steps out you off! If you can get a three wheeler or driver to take you to the upper car park you're half way there!  The final rock climb can be a bit tricky if you are not fit.  It is not so big at the top of the mountain but it is beautiful. When you go upstairs you van visit the stupa. You can also climb the rock and then you have an amazing view over the countryside. It is one of the religious places in Anurudhapura. Little bit far from the city centre about 7 km.   You have to climb plenty of steps to reach the attraction. It was uplifting to see that language was not a barrier. We climbed the rock and worshiped.  Everyone should go there to worship this historical place. At lower level you find a place called Refractory probably a place to store cooked food, two stone troughs ,large one for rice & smaller for curry. There are many spots for grinding spices. Above it a place having two granite inscriptions telling us records of payments to service staff. After further climbing you come to a plain platform area where you have to remove your shoes for further visit. There is a temple in center of this area. Now 3 peaks to climb One is having a Maha Stupa, no clear steps,climb with help of railing, 7-19 AD Another peak called Aradhana Gala) where Mahinda landed. Difficult for senior citizens to climb. Third peak has a Buddha statue. Stunning views from all peaks. Entry ticket- LKR 500/per person. No concession for SAARC nationals You find here Giant Squirrel ,national animal of Sri Lanka. Normal charges for guide LKR 1000, we hired in LKR 800 but came to know that guide is included in our package. Must visit place

This site lies 12 km east of Anuradhapura and was where buddahism was first introduced into Sri Lanka. As the historical evidence and archeological facts prove, Mihintale is the place where arahat Mihindu thero came to Sri Lanka from India and met Kind Devanampiya Tissa to introduce Buddhism to Sri Lanka. According to records, Mihintale forest is the oldest known protected sanctuary in the country. Kind Devanampiya Tissa declared the range as a protected zone for all the animals. There are few important places to visit in Mihintale. 1. Sela Chetiya (Dagoba) 2. Aradhana Gala (A small peak) 3. Mihindu Seya (Remains of Arahat Mihinu thero) 4. Khantaka Chetiya (Oldest surviving dagoba of Sri Lanka) 5. Mihindu Guhawa (The cave where Arahat Mihindu stayed) 6. Ancient hospital (only ruins) To cover the entire area of Mihintale, you need a full day. In ancient times, Mihintale was a Buddhist monastery with all the facilities for Bikkhu sangas. Still we can see the archeological evidence scattered all over the place.

The first meeting of introducing Buddhism to  King Devanampiyatissa the by a Buddhist monk Mahinda, migrated from India,  who was the son of Emperor Asoka(268 ‚Äì  232 BC), an Indian emperor of the Maurya Dynasty,  subsequently,  inaugurated the presence of Buddhism in Sri Lanka. Buddhist devotees strongly believe that the  team of Buddhist missioners, who considerd as  envoys of the king, had flown  to Mihintale rock from India by their spiritual power.   Legends state Emperor Asoka converted to Buddhism, after witnessing the mass deaths of the Kalinga War of India. These  are certain historical information connected with Mihintale. This is a flat terrain on top of a Mihintale rock, from where the  was supposed to have called King Devanampiyatissa, by the King‚Äôs first name to stop him shooting a deer in jungle.

It is not so big but it is beautifull to visist. When you go upstairs you van visit the stupa. You can also climb the rock and rhen you have a amazing view over the country.

Being birth place of Buddhism in Sri Lanka with a enchanting historical event occurred there, the place has plenty of history and very ancient ruins. It was worth the visit though no one checked our tickets and we had proactively gone and purchased them from a small booth in a corner. We get a feel of Buddhist monks daily lives 2000 years ago. Try hiking off trail steps in the site, it leads to more interesting ruins. Recommend visiting in evening when it gets cooler. Carry your own water + food as the place does not have any facilities including toilets.
we had fun we could not climb the rock but we worshiped so i think every one should go there to worship this historical place
I like Mihintale, it is very nice place, calm and lot of to see there. Also a nice view of landscape, It is worth to visit. Do not miss lion fountain opposite to parking. :)

The birthplace of buddhism in Sri Lanka. Very holy site, so make sure you have good socks or very strong feet. My wife suffered a little as it was hot walking barefooted on the rock. Some of the steps up to the top of the rock are a little slippy and it is not an easy descent, although you can grasp the had rail. The Buddha is also worth a visit, although it was far too hot for us to do the stupa's. Take a lot of water, although there is a shop to buy drinks. You have to visit and make it to the top of the rock - its an achievement and provides some lovely views. We were not bothered by the "Helpers", but we did have our driver with us.

Though the huge number of nice steps and the rock climbing seems to be the main part of Mihinthale journey; there are plenty of important things to see around there. One of a religious place in Anurudhapura. Little bit far from the city center. You have to climb plenty of steps to reach here. Can have a great view from here. There's a rock climbing too. From there you can have a breathtaking 360 view.

This is the birthplace of Buddhism on the island and we were looking forward to making the arduous climb to the rock pinnacle, however, the entire experience was marred by the so called 'Helpers' who lie in wait for tourists and engage in conversation with them, bringing out family photos etc to garner trust/sympathy. Once you have responded to conversation they have become your unwanted helpers at an undisclosed fee. As stated earlier, the climb to the pinnacle is quite arduous as one has to climb using small steps carved into the rock (there is a handrail to the top). If you are using the helpers, do yourselves a favour and negotiate a price prior to accepting their help. If you are considering the climb, do so in the early hours of the morning before the rock heats up. We had blistered feet from the experience as it is a temple and footwear is not allowed. Personally I will not take another group of mine there until the situation with the helpers is resolved as members of my group felt very uncomfortable with all the arm grabbing.

This is a must place to see when visiting Sri Lanka.    It is a spot of great relegious and historic significance, so modesty in dress for both men and women, bare feet and no head gear.  The complex is mostly carved into the rock and many steps to climb.   Visiting in the evening  is recommended to avoid the noon day heat.    A lot of steep climbing, not for the faint hearted.

This is a lovely historic place, plenty of steps to climb and most of it is barefoot. As it is of religious significance, shoulders and legs should be covered and no hats. My tip would be, if in doubt carry a wrap/sarong/shawl. My other tip would be to carry a pair of socks with you as the ground can get hot. The climb is manageable at a steady pace. However,  the very last bit for the views, is one way traffic only. This is where you meet 2 types of people; the impatient who barge by and the helpful who offer their hand as support, or who lift a child or make way for the old. It was uplifting to see that language was not a barrier.  We noticed the locals taking bags of stuff up with them and assumed it to do with 'pooja' but only at the top did we see that it was sand.  On descending we asked about it. ... the sand is being used to replace the foundation of the stones. We strongly suggested signs should be put up in various languages as had we known we would have carried a few bags up.

Visit in the morning! Nice climb and lots of places to see! Avoid poya time for calm and quiet experience. It has lot of archeological important areas still being discovered. Find a good guide, so you can have a valuable visit!

We ve been there at Sunset and the colors were beautiful. This site gather wonderful Dagobas, Bodhi Tree, Buddha and many other interesting curiosities. The final  rock climb can be a bit tricky if you re not fit but we had a 4 years old with us and she made it easily!

Nice site to visit. Note that the climbing is not too difficult. The different point of views are really great from there. You have a dagoba, a buddah statue and rock to climb, an ancient water pool, etc... so different things to see. Just be aware of the monkeys which can be a bit aggressive if you get to close to them.

Don't let the 1850 steps out you off! If you can get a tuktuk or driver to take you to the upper car park you're half way there! After your first climb, you've a few more but it's worth it for Lovely views from stupa, cave and nice breeze to refresh. Less touristic, so Had a really nice vibe to it. Lot of walking on hot stone or sand without shoes so bring socks if you wear flipflops!!
A must see, because you can see a very nice sunset! You will see a lot of monkey's and you see a big Buddha andere mihintale temple! Don't skip this, it's really worth it!

Went there in June 2017. Got there at about 8am, which was a good time because it was cool and none of the tourist buses had gotten there yet (by the time I left it was swarming). I was able to climb up and down the rock with no one else there, which was nice. Great view at the top. The railing is really necessary for the climb and if there were people going in the opposite direction I imagine that it would be difficult. Wish I could come on a poya day, esp. in Poson, where there is a festival there. Sites like this only come alive during festivals.

As most attractions in Sri Lanka Mihintale is overpriced. Then, when you arrive at the Budha statue one thing is clear; they don't use the entrance fee for cleaning up the place. You can take a tuktuk but a cheaper option is the bus. Sunset from the dagoda is nice as is the view but I would't spend so much money again.
That was our fourth day of visiting ruins or temples, so weren't too sure. But the views are well worth it!!

I went to Mihintale when I was on vacation with my parents. The place really is amazing. The climb to the mountaintop was somewhat hard on socks, but well worth it! I especially thought the huge white buddha statue was amazing! There were also a lot of moneys, which was fun :). Would highly recommend checking this place out!! However, if you have problems walking or walking stars, this might be to challenging for you.

Mihintale lies 8 miles east of Anuradhapura and is where Buddhism originated on the island. In 247 BC King DevanampiyaTissa of Anuradhapura. its a nice walk to the top of the mountain. and view is fantastic
