This is a must place to visit if you are to Anradhapura. Try to visit in the morning or evening hours because you will feel hard when its in the day time because of the heat.

This hillock is around 20 kms from Anuradhapura having a big stupa and buddha temple and surrounding ruins. This is believed to be the cradle of Buddhhisim in Sri Lanka where Mahinda son o Buddha is suppose to have given is first sermon. About half day worth visit.

Climb for only 12 minutes and you'll reach the main area. Then reach the rock, Buddha or temple in only another 5mins for each place. We spent a total of one hour and saw all three. It is only 10-15min drive/tuk tuk from the ancient city. Beautiful views from the rock and the buddha. We enjoyed this more than the ancient city. Highly recommend on a trip to this region.
You can climb up the main rock as well. The best time to visit during the sunset. It can be windy. The view from the top is spectacular!

An ancient place and historically important place for Sri Lankans as well as for Buddhism followers around the world. It is believed this is the place where  Lord Buddha's teachings arrived in SL. The then King who ruled the country started following Lord Buddha's teachings. Incredibly moving, peaceful and interesting place to visit. Be aware of the monkeys, they will grab anything from your hands, ice cream, flowers, phones!

What I think  is that if you haven't visited this place better hurry up. In my personal experience its really difficulty to carry flowers or food items to the top because of the monkeys around the walking parth are waiting  to drag them...scaryüò£
Minhintale was one of my most favourites places in Sri Lanka. beautiful, peaceful, scenic, not so crowded with tourists, definitely worth to visit

This place is an ancient place and a extremely historically important place for sri lankans as well as for buddhism followers around the world. This is believed to be the place where venerable mahinda thero arrived with lord buddhas teachings. The king who ruled the country then started following lord buddhas teachings. This is a place you can visit and spend a whole day freely. Take your children and have a great time spending understanding the countries history.

This is Sri Lanka's one of leading sacred places .... if you are willing to visit the sight recommend to visit in early morning or morning hours or else in bit late evening as the rock is not covered by any single tree it will literally burn you out... please wear nice n neatly as it's a religious place

We left early from Anuradhapura on our way to Sirigya with our driver and had this place largely to ourselves, and, though the top of the hill was covered in mist at first,  this added to the atmosphere.  We hired a guide at the start of the climb ‚Äì a must do ‚Äì and we really enjoyed our visit to this site.    For us, it was the best single place to visit in the Anuradhapura area.

15km/ 20mins drive from Anuradhapura City. Takes about 1-2 hours to climb to top. But needs at least one day to go through the entire archaeological structure. According to the history, this is the place where the Buddhism was brought to Sri Lanka. A sacred place for Buddhists. The important places to visit are, 1. Temple 2. Aaradhana Gala (Summit Rock) 3. Ambasthala Chethiya 4. Kantaka Chethiya 5. Sinha Pokuna (Lion Pond) 6. Naga Pokuna (Cobra Pond) 7. Kaludhiya Pokuna (Black water Pond) 8. Indigenous Hospital
We didn't climb from the lowest level but mid-level. The climb was very nice and easy. The view from the rock of the Dagoba was super.

Its believed to be the place where Arhat Mahinda met the then King of the country Devanampiyatissa and preached Buddhas doctrine to him. the king later converted to Buddhism. its believed the present Buddhist civilization of Sri Lanka formally initiated with this historic event. The place is now consist of ruins of a monastery, and caves believed to be the initial dwellings of Arhat Mahinda and his followers, Climbing the steep part of rock is after the thousands of stone stairway is an adventure. If you visit the place during sunset or sunrise you would not regret. its such a beautiful scenery. dont forget to take your camera.

This site has 3 main areas, all at the top of hills, all of which you go up bare foot. The rock was definitely worth the climb, as the view was spectacular. We went around the stupa (white hemisphere) and finally went up to the big Buddha statue for sunset. The views are amazing, the site is stunning and it was definitely worth going to see

This is well worth the climb. The ruins were really interesting and the views at the top were speculative. Try not to go in the middle of the day like us as it's very hot. Also you cannot wear shoes on the walk and the stone steps get extremely hot!

Better to visit this place in the evening due to hot whether. wear trousers because you are about to climb a giant rock. Lots of monkeys in surrounding area.take only the water bottles and cameras with you. monkeys might steal. nice view in the evening. Sacred place. good example of rich culture.

A bit of a climb, something I let my husband do while I sat this one out, being a bit dubious when sharing a set of steep, narrow stone cut stairs and one handrail with people moving in the opposite direction.  My husband tells me the views from the top were great, but I enjoyed the views from lower down as well.  Like a lot of religious sites it is shoes off for quite a bit of the time you are in the general area - so take a pair of socks as the ground can get very hot.  Much more to see than just climbing the rock, US$10 so one of the cheaper sites in Sri Lanka.  A lot of pilgrims when we went, which made it very special.
Nice location to see some heritage from this area over the nudism and have a nice walk over the stairs and area
Worth a visit, especially to get you into training for the later climbs (Sigiriya, Adm's Peak)! Various things to see once you reach the top, and also good views.

The place is amazing. The views, unforgettable and the history, for me, the best of all history places of Sri Lanka. There are not a lot of tourist and you can enjoy all zones better than other tourists places. I will come back when I will travel again to this area. Ayubowan!

Amazing view from the rock after a scramble up. Also a beautiful and well maintained Buddha statue and Dagoba. City guides offer service, but we enjoyed exploring by ourselves. Choose a cooler time to climb as bare feet or socks are required and the rocks get quite hot.

Mihintale is a must in this area of Sri Lanka.  The temples, caves and water tanks are all fascinating and the views incredible.  There are areas adjacent to the main temple which are often missed and deserve exploring.  Luckily we visited as soon as it opened in the morning since it was a significant climb on variable surfaces and steps and it gets hot quickly.  For me (not too much hair...) having to remove my hat, protecting my fair skin from the sun, was not convenient, nor was having to remove footwear for the last part of the climb on uneven rock and gravel surfaces.  These measure were necessary because of the religious nature of the site and I had no option but to respect this.  But visitors ought to be aware.  Perhaps sun cream on the head and thick socks?

A beautiful and serene place where Mahinda, son of the Indian King Asoka, converted King Devanampiya Tissa to Buddhism in 3rd century BC. This "sacred Hill of Mihintale" is less visited than the sites of Polonnaruwa and Anuradhapura, but should be a must see because of its history, scenery and serenity. Visit in the morning preferably as it gets very hot. No shoes allowed. The visit should take a couple of hours with a good guide. For the more daring, a climb to Aradhana Gala (Meditation Rock) is worth the effort (it is very steep on narrow steps - remove your socks if you kept them as the steps carved out of the rock can be slippery). From the top, the view over the plain, the Dagoba and the Buddha statue is breathtaking.
There is not much to see in a tourist way but this place can bring peace to your mind. The guide took us to a small hermitage. Monks are still living here.

we have been there in the late afternoon, when it was not that crowded. from the parking lot, it takes you a five minutes walk over some steps to reach the top of the place. there you will see a beautiful buddha statue, a stupa and a sacred hilltop, where you can climb up. from the top you have a wide and beautiful view over the countryside and you can also see the stupas from anuradhapura. it takes about two hours to explore the whole place, and it is really worth it. not that crowded and very beautiful!
Nice nature around, best view to area, spoilt monkies, kind monks, calming music, fresh water, lot od stairs

Climbing to the top of the rock is an adventure rewarded by wonderful views. Walking and climbing barefoot is not for a tenderfoot. This is one of the original sites of Buddhism in Sri Lanka and even the ruins recall an impressive history.
It is a decent walk, you need to be on steady feet as it can be quite slippery however, the view is worth the trek up to the top

Rather a last minute decision to visit and only arrived by tuk tuk at 4.30 but place not heaving though one large school party there. The temple complex is beautiful and the views stunning especially with thunderstorm in the distance. I would recommend wearing socks but the walk up the steps is far easier than expected though would not recommend at the heat of the day and good value at 500 rupees

This is such a beautiful attraction and is a must see - the view is amazing! Just be warned that you have to take your shoes off & climbing up the rock in midday heat barefooted (like we did!) is unbearable - take socks! Also make sure your shoulders and knees are covered otherwise they will not let you in.

Well worth the drive out to Mihintale, one of the best sites in the Anuradhapura area and at a fraction of the cost.  Amazing views and we had a superb guide, have posted a pic of him (can't remember his name!)

Mihintale is not far from Anuradhapura, accessible through bus or tuktuk, about 10km I think. The entrance fee is ok and it's worth to take a guide who shows you the area. Take about 1.5h time and take a nice picture just below the summit in a narrow niche between the rocks, you can lay down on a stone and take a nice picture! Guide was 1000. we negotiated him down to 500 but were so happy to give him the full amount (which made him happy as well:-))
This tour is best in the afternoon to see the sunset. A good idea to take a guide which will approach you in the car park.

You must see it. It was one of the best area in North Sri Lanka. There is a lot of ruins, temples, viewpoints and temples with buddhas and monks. Bring socks with you because you must get down your shoes before entry and ground could be really hot.
A must see place!  Breathtakingly beautiful. Lots of steps, however so worth it! A piece of tranquility and beauty.

This was first visit on our Sri Lankan holiday and an introduction to the necessity of removing one`s shoes when visiting these holy sites. As some reconstruction was underway, and builders grit had been left around it was quite painful for my pathetic western feet! Worth and visit and great views.

This is special as it's the where Buddhism started in Sri Lanka! Frankly, the place is bigger than I expected.  It was a blessing in disguise when I arrived at 2pm, way earlier than planned. The sun was blazing but I decided to go ahead!  I was able to enjoy the sights due to the lesser crowd and the time to spare, helped by the occasional passing clouds and nice breeze.  At one point, I was the only one on top of the meditation rock - Aradhana Gala.  The climb can be taxing and risky; so take your time and watch your steps!  The socks helped but the grip can be compromised too. Overall, I enjoyed the sights and experience - it's a place not to be missed!
We will never forget this experience. The climb is very difficult and potentially dangerous. The view from the top is outstanding. The whole climb has to be made shoeless and hatless

Mihintale hilltop is a very spiritual place, with several sights, also offering great sunset views. The 1800 steps are far less strenuous than they sound, it takes about 20' to the top. Mind that it can be crowded.

On arrival we met a guide who offered to show us around. We were glad he did. From what we planned to be a 30 min visit we spent 90min learning whilst taking some great pictures. I would highly recommend that you too seek him out.

It's a one hour ride by bike from Anuradhapura and an approx. 20 minutes walk up. Entrance fee is Rs. 500 and on the top you'll habe the chance to go up to three different peaks. We enjoyed the one with the dagoba most. Btw: There's some maintenance work going on at the moment, bit still wort a visit.
Worth seeing for the black pond which is very tranquil, and climbing the "rock". We went on a weekend which was busy but a real experience seeing and meeting Sri Lankan people on a day out.

A visit is best with a local guide whom will provide the background story which will make the Visit much more interesting. With do many choice to chose from in  Anuradhapura this is highly recommended and cost only 500Rb .
It's always interesting to find out more about the roots of a culture by learning about its early history and this is a great site to begin your exploration of the surrounding sites.
A very nice place to visit in around 1 to 2 hours. Amazing to see at sunset. Peaceful and quiet, with a great view on the region from the top of the big rock !

This is the mountain where Buddhism was introduced to sri Lanka by Ven Arahat Mahinda and Inian saint to the King Devanam Piyatissa 2500 years ago and is an important place to visit.  It could be crowded during Full Moon days, the mountain top can be climbed all protections are available. very peaceful place and important for any Buddhist specially.
Don't miss the sunset on the top of the mountain. Awesome views.you have to climb a few steps so take water bottles with you. Only 13km east of anuradhapura. Don't miss this.
We visited in afternoon as too hot during the day. have to take shoes and hats off so bit hard on feet. but worth a visit.

We came along and went up here spent about 2 hours and LOVED it. There are three things, the stupa, the Buddha and the rock, it's worth climbing up to all. The views are amazing. It's just 500 a person entrance and absolutly beautiful!!!

You can climb from the main car park at the bottom right up to the Mahaseya Dagoba at the summit but simpler to take your transport three quarters of the way up to the higher entrance. You can be helped by the rock boys for a few rupees the rest of the way from there. The reference to 1840 steps must include the whole of the complex and not the direct route up, which many of our 60+ age group did! For those who want a thrill try barefoot up Aradhana Gala (meditation hill) - with help!

Great place to go and learn about the philosophy of Buddhism. The temples are incredible, you will also see the so called oldest tree in the world where locals visit and present their offerings. You can also be blessed here if you wish, lovely place.

Many steps but there is a road that will bring you 1/2 way up, we were there in Independence Day for Sri Lanka so many wonderful Sri Lankan folks visiting, the place where the monks ate is not to be missed with a big trough where the rice was put and a smaller one for the veggies

It is definetly worthwhile to visit Mihintale for a half a day from Anuradhapura. It is easy to get here by public transport. The temple and the view from on top of the hill are beautifull and the hike uphill isn't too tough. Especially nice is that there are not so many tourists here, which gives it a more authentic feeling. Take socks with you, because on the top the sand and stones can be pretty hot on the feet, as shoes are not allowed.

There was a nice path and trees were grown both the sides of stairway till the rock with ruins and beautiful carvings. You can climb the rock and maha stupa to get a really nice view of the surrounding. You meet with lot of ruins and architecture to see.

Walking here was hot and tiring, which works well with trying to get into a time zone and sleeping later. Distance is not far but its difficult as the final bit is up 'steps' (basic ledges) cut in the rock with a wobbly handrail and people (friendly sri lankans) going up and down at the same time. Be brave and careful, its slippery - the views at the end of it are wonderful, with the white buddha on a nearby rocky hilltop and a green panorama as far as the eye can see. Unforgetable.

Unfortunately we visited in heavy rain and we're unable to full appreciate the site. There are many steps up to the top but there is also an upper car park which does reduce the number you have to climb. You need to take your shoes off quite early and there is a lot of walking in bare feet. Despite the weather we were able to climb up to the viewing point, this is a difficult climb and also up to the stupa, this climb is much easier.

Nice place to see if in the area. We were unlucky enough to get caught in a heavy rain shower at the top. Very dangerous as you are barefoot. Shoes must be given in before entry (after all of the steps of course!). Appropriate clothing also required. 500lrk p/p entry. A lot of steps but won't take too long. Plenty of tour guides there if you want one!

My favourite place , so much to discover and the views are amazing. We had a guide who explained all so well, loved the story of how Buddhism started there under the Mango tree. Unfortunately we only did the top bit and missed the first level, caves etc. As it was late to do it all.

Nice place, where Mahinda introduced Buddhism to the king of Sri Lanka. You have to climb some steps and most of it without your shoes, so it's wise to go early. This way you avoid the heat and don't burn your feet on all the hot stone surfaces everywhere. Or: wear small socks. Stupa's, rockviewpoint & big buddha statue nice.

Mihintale This is the birthplace of Buddhism in Sri Lanka and as such is a highly religious place for the faithful. It is not an easy place to get to as there are some two hundred steps, some fairly new, some at the top are extremely worn and slippery. Once at the top you will see a large Buddha to the left on the top of another hill, so more steps. In front there is a small coloured Stupa. On the right is a large Stupa on top of another hill, so more steps. Finally up more stairs is a rock outlook point with fantastic views. Unfortunately it was quite misty on the day of our visit. Beware the unofficial guides who are simply there for your money, although they can be a source of good information for a price. Make sure to take water. At the bottom, the younger males were being asked to carry bags of rubble to the top not just to impress there girlfriends but to earn life points. We even saw a group of four lads carrying large granite slabs on poles, presumably to repair the stairs.
We walked up during a cerimony of the full moon. It has been very nice, spiritual and of course amazing view!

We visited in the evening when most of the other travelers were leaving.  Encountered a large troup of monkeys on the first set of steps (there are many).  Some good views from the top, but not a good choice for a hot day.  1000 rupee admission fee is excessive.

The drive up to the halfway point at Mihintale was lovely as it is shaded by mature trees that are home to many Monkeys. The mango trees were all either flowering or in fruit and we were able to see many of the monkeys impatiently harvesting unripened mangos for their troops. The entrance fee to Mihintale was approximately 1,000.00 Rupees for two. There is parking at the halfway point entrance. There are some stalls selling drinks at the car park and also at the halfway point when climbing. Just beyond the entrance, there are several ruins to view and then to climbing the steps towards the summit.Unfortunately we attempted the climb at almost midday and the heat was rather oppressive. As a result, we decided against the full climb to the top. There is a halfway point in the climb where one can rest at a small stall selling cold drinks. At this point, you can get a glimpse of the main stupa at the top.

Mihinthale is important place in sri lanka. many people visiting Anuradhapura might get tired after visiting many of the points. and miss this in addition to being the spot where Buddhism was supposed to have originated in Sri lanka. There is nice veiw.
We couldn't find some of the places because there weren't any signs in English - this would be ok if we hadn't paid more than locals to enter.

I had been a little put off the climb of over 1800 steps suggested in our guide book. However, as our driver drove partway the ascent was much more manageable. I felt it to be a wonderful peaceful location with lots of pilgrims dressed in white ascending and descending the steps with flowers. The climb to the highest platform was beyond me as the steps looked slippery but my husband (aged65) managed it easily as did many others. The hospital at the base was most interesting.
Visited here as part of a day tour of the cultural triangle. Yet another peaceful place in this amazing Country

A must visit place when you touring Anuradhapura, this is the place where Buddhism first came to Sri Lanka. A very beautiful and scenic place and worth every steep step you climb to see the temple. Highly recommended...

Many people visiting Anuradhapura might get tired after visiting many of the points in teh town and miss this in addition to being the spot where Buddhism was supposed to have originated in Sri Lanka, there are a couple of small climb / hike options that make the location very interesting

The place of origin of Buddhism in Sri Lanka, this temple atop a mountain is surrounded with an abundance of ruins and Archaeological treasures. The ruins of old monastery, the shrine rooms, the large dining halls and the old hospital are worthy attractions. The climb up, to the temple along a never ending flight of steps, in the shades of blooming Temple trees is a truly amazing experience, and finally the view from the top of the mountainous rock is breathtaking. Really worth visiting.

Climbed up to the base of mihintale which was quite steep. It is 1200 steps e tra Ro the top so we gave it a miss.  Lots of monkeys on the walk up and our guide advised us to put our water in our backpack to stop monkeys from grabbing out of our hands.  Was advised not to hire one of th guides that hang around offering their services.  Careful as once you start nagging with the and they walk with you consider them hired!

A tranquil and beautiful place with 360 views of the countryside at the top. 500 rupee entry fee. From Anuradhapura it will cost you about 1500 rupee return by tuk tuk including driver waiting for you for the sunset in the late afternoon. The hardest part of the walk is the small pebbles on the way for people with soft feet. Keep going it's worth it.
We visited this temple during our Anuradapura tour. Temple is located in a very nice area and the ancient buildings were great. Loved this place too.

This is the place where Buddhism first arrived in Sri Lanka. Worth climbing up to see the stupa and the Buddha statue. The rock however gets really busy with the queue especially during school holidays. A small entrance fee but get ready to walk a fair way without your shoes. Enjoy the view at the top.
A significant place of worship for Buddhists of the country. This place is a cliff. But i would not recommend this  place  for small children.
We were lucky to be here during the long xmass weekend and experience first hand  the pilgrimage of Sri lankans at this special and peaceful place.
Mihintale is definately a spot to be visited once you are in Sri Lanka. It is by far not so crowded as Anuradhapura or Pollunaruwa. walk up and enjoy the peace.

This is a sacred place for people who follow Buddhism. It's considered that King Ashok's son and daughter came here and preached Buddhism . There are ruins which date back a couple of thousand years back. The view from top is quite nice. Found a couple of old ladies going all the way up to the hill top. The climb to the top isn't an easy one. And risky if it rains. Overall nice experience. We took a guide too who narrates us stories.
If one is interested about the historical places a must see. According to Sri Lanka history Arhath Mihindu has preached the first Buddhist sermon to the king of Sri Lanka at this peak.
Take a tuk tuk around. This gives you great access with plenty to see. You need at least a full day.

Mihintale is a spiritual place of deep significance to Buddhists and Sri Lankans. As well as a large stupa, there is a smaller, more decorated one around which ceremonies are performed, and a monumental Buddha statue. I would recommend travelling here late in the afternoon once the heat of midday has reduced, as there's quite a long ascent to the top of the hill (and you don't want scorched feet at the top!); plus there seems to be more activity and ceremony in the early evening so it's a nice place to chill out and soak in the atmosphere.

The object of the exercise is to climb to the top of this bare rock to admire the view. Footholds are non-existent for large parts of the climb and handholds shakey at best. All this in bare feet and under a baking sun - I'm still not sure why we did it. The view from the top is great though and there is a certain camaraderie that builds up with your fellow climbers even when there is no common language.
Budhist temple with a sri lankan background history. Climbed with my family including 2 young children (just above 1year). Nice view at the top. Spiritual place
This Buddhist religious place should be on everyone itinerary to North Central Sri Lanka. It is the location of introduction of Buddhism to the island nation over two thousand years ago.

Was recommended a visit to Mihintale on my first night in Anuradhapura, and to be honest, i enjoyed seeing this more than the ancient ruins. The site is about 11km out of town, and should be roughly around 1500lkr if going by tuktuk, 2000lkr if you have a guide. Climbing up the steps was great fun, and climbing to the viewing point was one of the highlights.  It's worth coming here in the afternoon and watching the sun set. Also, if you have a guide, expect to spend a good few hours here, otherwise, it can be done in a shorter amount of time

From Anuradhapura, we went by bus to Mihinthale. It was recommended by our hotelowner and it did not disappoint. We did not take the steps right away, but went right and then left on the main road. After 150m we went left again to get to the stairs that lead to the temple. (We should have continued another 250m on the main road to visit the black water pond). Before you get to the temple there are some ruins that are interesting. On top you can see the budda, the temple and a nice view from the rock. It recommended that you take some socks with you because the rock can be very hot and you will have to walk without shoes or slippers.

We went there in November 2016 enjoyed every minute there. There is quite a lot of climbing but then you get rewarded with an amazing view over Anuradhapura and a huge Buddha statue. On our visit there was not so much to see because of the fog but I believe when it's really clearly that the view must be even more amazing!

Nothing spectacular, but the way to the place with massive stair cases and monkeys around are spectacular. Also, once climbed you can see spectacular surrounding with lush gardens, lakes and sthupas around.

this is a bustling but at times very tranquil and peaceful place.  the light can be amazing and the large viewing rock isn't great if you don't like heights are a stickler for health and safety and don't like crowds.  even if you are a stickler for health and safety just avoid the big rock and enjoy the rest of the site - ooh and the socks is for the gravel and the, at times, heat underfoot as no shoes can be worn.  we took socks with us after out first temple visit and they really do make everything more pleasant without shoes and it is perfectly acceptable.

This mountain peak is located about 13KM from Anuradapura. About 1800 steps to climb, seems a lot of psychical activities but in my experience a good half an hour would be enough to reach the top. You can enjoy the fresh wind, calm and peaceful environment on the top. This sacred mountain is so special among the Buddhist because they believe lord Buddha had visited this place. Good time to climb around 3PM so you can enjoy the sunset and the view.

The Mihintale Museum is located just before you enter the main temple, it is not advertised much, but if you visit this place one can gather a lot of information. Not well maintained on the outside, but quite well maintained inside. Well worth a visit. Be careful of the Monkeys who are real pests, as they can harm you.

We thought it would be nice to get a guide, wo drives us around the different temples/dagoba's/ruines/holy places of Anuradhapura, but after the 5th dagoba or pile of stones we where literally done with everything. We ended here in Mihintale, wishing i spend my day differently than walking trough Anuradhapura. Mihintale is awesome, awesome view over Anuradhapura an beautiful sunset, if the weather is with you. Best place to visit! Dont skip this one!

The history says it's a prestige and importance location of the Buddhism of the country. The rock is the highest location of the Anuradhapura resulting magnificent view to the city. The rock staircase is one of the attracting places. Further, ancient stupa and Buddha statue are two important places to visit. The location is about 15 kilometers away from the Anuradhapura main city and any vehicle can accessible via road. The visitor requires climbing large number of steps to reach the location and therefore it requires an attention for elders and child. Further, visitors should pay attention to the large gathering of monkeys in the vicinity and it advised not to feed.
We've done Adams Peak and Sigiriya but this was a wonderful way to finish or trip. We did sunrise and only ones there. Sat and watched for an hour. Best thing to do!
A good place close to Anuradhapura with a huge Ancient rock Temple. This is the place Bhuddhism was introduced to Sri Lanka by Ven Monk Mihindu from India. Overall a place worth a visit in any angle.

Having visited Anuradhapura in the past it was lovely to find quiet and beautiful Mihintale and to climb up the many steps exploring the ruins set among frangipani trees early in the morning before many pilgrims arrived. A most interesting and sacred Buddhist site with superb views from the dagoba  set on top of the hill.

After traveling to Sri Lanka to see the historical treasures, we were put off by 2 things. the high cost of entrance fees (85% higher than locals) and the underwhelmed reviews of fellow traveler. We poured over the photos of "free" areas vs "Expense Entry Fee" areas and frankly we could not see any difference. Therefore, we toured with the intent to NOT pay any of the "Expensive Entry Fees". The thing about the ruins in Sri Lanka is that only the foundations are left and they are not well kept. The dagobas that have been maintained look brand new. We were advised to take a lunch, which sounded like a great idea, but as soon as we sat down about 20 aggressive moneys appeared, growling and grabbing.  We quickly left, climbed 500 steps and found a security guard sitting in a big cage behind the ticket office. He kindly allowed us to eat our lunch inside the cage while money's drooled outside. We appreciated visiting Minhintale for very little money, but, removing ones shoes and hats ( out of respect for the Buddha), then walking over scorched hot sand and rock, seemed pointless while stepping over plastic bags and litter. After spending 3 hot dry days in Anuradhapura, we jumped off the Cultural Triangle Trail and are spending the rest of our days at the Beach. While Sri Lanka is a lovely country with lovely people, if you want to see ruins, go to Angkor Wat or Myanmar.

You climb a lot of stairs from the parking area up to the stupa other sites. You will be offered a guide at the parking area. I declined as I didn't feel like I really needed one and had my driver/guide with me. Nice views over the surrounding areas from the top. We went late afternoon and were there for sunset which was pretty good.

It's a peak of a mountain which is believed that Arahat Mahinda visited and inaugurated the presence of Buddhism. According to chronology this is the site Where King Devanampiyathissa and the Bhikkuhas met. From the ancient time the large steps (more than 1000) were constructed (carved in rock) to climb Mihinthale. NOTE: Climbing in the evening is easy and do not want to miss the beautiful sunset. Amazing Sunset that you can enjoy.

Don't miss the sunset on the top of the mountain!  The Buddha statue is one of the most beautiful we have seen! If you get hot in your foot,  bring socks,  but if you go in the afternoon like us,  you won't be needing them.

Located 11Km from the Anuradhapura ancient city. The premises is more beautiful at night but the beautiful scenery from top of the rock cannot be seen. I have been there at late evening and also on another day.... Advised to cover the entire premised including Mihindu Guhawa

A great place with so much knowledge about the ancient way of life and the amazing technology at that time. Also a very important spiritual place for Buddhist. Late afternoon and early evening is a great time to climb and experience the spiritual and the visual journey.
Nice to visit the historic monuments and old structures. Special if you are an historic fan !!! Journey is nice !!!

I've been brought to this place by the hotel owner. He told me not to miss this and he was right. On top of the mountain, climb the stairs to the Stupa (on your right) and watch the sunset from the deck: BREATHTAKING! I recommend you take a look at the other sights befor it gets dark. It's quite a climb with 1840 stairs and if you're in no good condition, you can drive halfway and start there ;-) Remind yourself to cover your shoulders and knees. If you don't have it, you can borrow sarongs there for free (where you leave your shoes/flip flops)

Awesome views! I can say that I have never seen this beautiful scenery. You have to climb a few steps so take some snack and water bottle with you if you feel that you might need it. Entrance fee was 500rs and that was totally worth it! Don't miss this! Highest rock was bit hard to climb was all the other places you can reach easily!

One of the greatest places we visited in Sri Lanka. We went here an hour before sunset and had a splendid view over the surrounding area from both the temple and Mihintale rock. Absolutely recommendable. There are plenty of steps though, so remember to wear good shoes and bring water.

To be honest, we are a little spoiled on temples and other touristic sights, but we enjoyed going to Mihintale. The trip by tricycle from Anuradhapura was fun to begin with, a nice ride through the area. We payed Rs. 2000 together and our driver waited for us in the parking lot. Don't be frightened by the 1800 steps, they are spread out over several sights, so you don't have to climb them all. The dagoba and Buddha statue are impressive, even to us spoiled travellers! Bring socks to prevent burned feet. Shoes and slippers are well taken care of.

Only 13km east of Anuradhapura, Minhintale is well worth a visit in the early morning or late afternoon when the sun is not so hot. You have it all here; plenty of holy-place steps to tone those calves, ancient history and ruins, a living holy site with dagobas and bodhi tree, a rock summit with magnificent views of the surrounding countryside and naughty Macaque monkeys. Mihintale has been associated with the earliest introduction of Buddhism to Sri Lanka. It is a place where you might benefit from the services of a guide. It really is a lot of fun struggling up the final stone steps to the summit with all the locals. There is a rail so hold on tight.
We went there from Anuradhapura to see the sunset, and it was really beautiful, I would really recommend to go because it's not very far away from Anuradhapura and you can get there by bus
Nice walk up to the temple area. There's a ceremony for the sunset on top of one of the rock, but we climbed up to the other rock. It was pretty windy up there but view was breathtaking!

Great views when you walk up to the big stupa or the other viewpoint. Entrance for foreigners Rs500. We got a tuktuk from Anuradhapura for Rs1500, waited 2hours for us and then drove back. You walk a lot on the site on bare foot which is pretty hot at times (saw lot of people with socks on, probably a smart idea). We didn't stay until sundown but I guess that will be a very nice view. Lots of (cheeky) monkeys for nice photographs but look out they don't take your belongings..!
It will take around one hour to climb to the top..If you are a budhdhist this is a must visit place..View is marvolous from top of the rock!!
Excellent site for views of the anuradhapura region with a beautiful giant sitting buddha. Modest entrance price of 500 well worth it.

It is good to see another aspect of this area that has so many interesting and mysterious places, climbing to the top of the rock gives you a good perspective and is well worth it. Not sure how slippery it gets in the rain or how crowded, both would make the experience less enjoyable.
It is worth to visit Mihnthale with your friends and Family . It is nice place to be with your loving ones.

Loved climbing this. The main climb takes about 25 minutes and isn't too bad. You have to take your shoes off half way up which makes climbing the rock a little trickier. Climbing the main rock is a mixture of steps and actually climbing but the view is breathtaking.

It is very nice temples complex. You can see old antic ruins, a big modern white stupa, a big white budha, wonderful views and interesting monks habits. I think it is more interesting than old Anuradaphura antic city.

we have been lucky we had a great local guide (who we ended up paying twice the amount we agreed upon out of our own initiative) we therefore received a great explanation and background about the history of this place (and the area), he even turned out to be a good photographer. The entry fee (as of summer 2016) is 500 RS per person for foreigners

The climb can be done in 2 ways. There is an easy way from the park and another hard way. I took the hard way but its not that bad and enjoyed and glad that i made it to the top. There are about 2000 stairs and the top is the Mihindu gala where the Mihindu thero appeared to king Dewanam piyathissa during Anuradapura monarch. There is a huge buddha statue and a stupa and the view is significant.

Our favorite site at the area of Anuradhapura. Climbing the stairs is not hard (not from the car parking anyway), the ancient part near the parking help to understand how the monks lived those days. But it is it is the top of the hill-top that makes everything grand. The views to the site itself and all the area is wonderful.
A small uphill hike leads to a  wonderful site and views. The statutes are well maintained and yet the steps to them are carved into the rock

We visited as a group and had our holiday guide show us around. This is a beautiful, peaceful complex with stunning views of the surrounding countryside and of the statues and buildings here. Top tip: Bring socks in warm weather to put on to walk on the sand / steps as it gets incredibly hot. Don't miss this wonderful place if you're in the area.
Well worth the visit. Be prepared for some 1840 steps plus some walking. Better to visit sometime in the evening as it will be slightly cooler. August is extremely hot here.

Climbing the first part of the rock is very interesting as there are steps and a line of temple tree to shade there. The small rock called 'Aradhana gala' there are no clearly cut steps.Difficult to climb with the wind. Rock is slippery.

We went to Mihintale simply to see the sight and climb the 1840 steps. It's a very good site if you are around (possibly in Anuradhapura) but I wouldn't recommend traveling a long distance just to see Mihintale. It's very crowded and noisy so the basic idea of "meditating while climbing" looks to be more of a myth. You cannot go inside the temple and like most holy sites it's required that you take off your shoes, which is a little tough with the stone burning up.

We went there as a surprise as we did want to travel from Anuradhapura to Trincomalee...luckily we looked at the map and decided to make a stop here. What an incredible place to visit..beware of all the stairs!! We where spotted by a guide and.....fair is fair...he gave us a fantastic tour.... Be aware at the area were you need to leave your shoes that you have some socks to protect your feet from the heat of the stones!üòê.... It is worthwhile to put this on your travel list.

Make sure you wear something that covers your knees. They will offer you cloth to wrap around for a small fee if you do not have appropriate clothing. Stairs up but not to strenuous, you can stop on your way up. Very peaceful with great views.

This place is special. Don't miss it!  Much preferred it to the main sites in Anaradapura and the kids liked it too. The climb to the top of the 'rock' is a little tricky and gets a little crowded so patience is required.

This is my most favourite place among all visited place in Sri Lanka. You have to climb a lot of steps, be prepared. Take a guide, it is worth than roaming alone. My guide agreed for 200 Srilankan Rupees. Watching sunset is a surreal experience, so please go in the afternoon. You will surely love the place, greenery and water bodies in the surrounding area.

my driver recommended me to visit it at this time of the afternoon to avoid the midday heat. The Stairway is a series of flights, 1843 ancient granite slab steps lead majestically up the hillside. On the second landing I took on the services of a guide (Rs 1000), it is also where the monks‚Äô refectory is located with huge stone troughs that the lay followers kept filled with rice for the monks. Nearby, at a place identified as the mon¬¨astery‚Äôs relic house, are two inscribed stone slabs erected during the reign of King Ma¬¨hinda IV. The final steep stairway, lined with frangipani trees, leads to the place where Mahinda and the king met. The Am¬¨basthale Dagoba is built over the spot where Mahinda stood. The bodhi tree to the left of the base of the steps is said to be one of the oldest surviving ones. From here there is a fantastic view over the lakes and trees to Anuradhapu¬¨ra, a horizon studded with the domes and spikes of all the massive dagobas. The guide did prove valuable as he had to race back up the steps to retrieve my camera that I had left on a bench whilst putting my sandals back on. There were also plenty of resident Macquae Monkeys, Langur Monkeys and a lone giant squirrel.

Not really a lot I can add other than worth taking a guide, lots of history you won't get otherwise. Very quiet for tourists and lots and lots of locals. We became a bit of an attraction with local kids with them photo bombing us. They were so friendly. Summed up Sri Lanka for us. The views are just amazing, have I said amazing enough. 500 steps up, be warned but old locals doing do no excuses.

We visited this place in the afternoon. Around 4 pm is the recommended time because of the heat. You have to walk on your socks or bare feet and the stones and sand can be very hot. We had a guide and he explained everything very well. We also visited some secret hidden spots. The sunset is also very nice to. Overall a beautiful attraction!
Good temples some interesting sites the old hospital is thought provoking a lot of steps to some amazing views back to Anuradhapura and other directions
This is only place where you can see clear sunset in Anuradhapura. But it is 18Km away from Milano Hotel.
Lots to see for a couple of hours if you dont mind walking steps. I advise to go early morning then its not too hot there. Certainly a must see when you pass by
Went here to admire the three temples & sunset. It was a good workout but worth it. We went by tuk tuk.
the visit is active with a lot of steps (careful if vertigo..),  and a mix of tourists and local people. Views are impressive around. The wind is welcome to cool down on tops !
Have been here before and had to see it again. An amazing place. Amazing views, Buddha and large Dagoba. The large stairway leading up to the site is magnificent. A must see.

We should have thought more but schedule was tight so out in the midday sun! It's hot. Get a guide and hear about monks life's and the beginning of Buddhism. Truly beautiful spot . A couple of hours here to ponder and climb stairs

Tuk-tuk from main city is a ride in itself.  Took a guide to explain history (normally don't do this) and was well-worth it.  Late afternoon climb during pre-Poya week was accompanied by pre-recorded chanting (and not many tourists).  Wonderful views at top, but be prepared to walk barefoot on rock steps at top end.

I think it was best place in Anuradhapura actually. It was a little bit tiring to reach the peak as there are many stairs (and we did it around 1pm when temperature was extremely hot) but it was worth it as the views are stunning and we learnt a lot about Buddhism. We went with local guide which was talking really interestingly and showing us little things that possibly would be missed but at the end he wasn't very happy about tip we gave him and was trying to make us feel guilty about it what kinda ruined my first feelings about the trip.

We are fascinated by the history/legend of this place. It is a significant place for Sri Lanka Buddhism. The stairs were easy as they were not high or large. When nearer the landing (Ambasthala Dagaba) - that leads to Stupa, Buddha and Aradhana Gala), you have to deposit your shoes (tip them Rs25 after you collect your shoes when you completed your visit) From landing onward, no shoes and attire must cover below knee. There were some steps toward Maha Stupa. The view from the Maha Stupa is beautiful. The steps up the Aradhana Gala is alittle more challenging as they aren't well formed steps. Some steps were created out of carves into the boulder. However it isn't a long way up. I didn't manage to take photos as i had to keep my hands on railing as it was so windy. Overall it is a well worth visit, especially if you read about the story behind it.

If there is just one thing in Anuradhapura you can do the go to Mihintale! I liked it better then the old city in Anuradhapura. We got there with a a tuk tuk but there is also a public bus. From the main parking space you need to walk up the stairs 15 min or you can ask the driver to park at an upstairs parking lot. The entrance is 500 Rp per person. Our kids were free. On the main area is a giant Buddha statue a large rock that you can climb and a giant stupa. We went there just before sunset and had some amazing views from the rock and stupa. Reeeeealy nice!!

Mihintale consists of a couple of old ruins, and the upper sanctuary with a holy cave, and three holy objects accesible through carved out steps. It's a very quiet and magical place. The accompanied prayers from a buddhist monk, broadcasted trough the whole sanctuary, only add to the atmosphere. The sunset can be viewed from either dagoba or the highest peak/rock. There's a no shoe policy, so take some socks on hot days to save your feet from burning. The climb to the top of the rock has some sloping steps carved out, although the railing is nice and strong, some fitness is recommended. Sadly, at the top of the rock while crouching to take some pics, my sunglassess dropped down out of my pocket. They have some dioptric correction in them. If anyone finds them, treat them well!
Definitely worth a stop, the rock was a little treacherous to climb as it is was quite busy but added to the fun of it and the view from the top was certainly worth it

This site can be visited after / together Anaradhapura site . It is a very historical site as it is where Buddhism began in Sri Lanka . Get a guide to explain you all the history and details about how the monks lived up there . Do not miss to climb up to the rock where the view is amazing !
Plenty of history , ruins and steps. Please take out the modern street lighting - it completely spoils the feeling of this ancient city

Interesting enough but it seems to be a magnet for guides who won't take "no" for an answer.When you arrive,they appear by the car and ,even if told that they are neither wanted follow you around the site,supply the odd snippet of information and then look doleful and offended if not paid once back at the car,regardless of the fact that they were told they were not needed,earlier .This appears to be their MO In other respects,the site has a high admission fee and,whilst interesting,appears over stated.
Highly recommended value for money wormly welcome Working distortion bus station. Secrect site. Train station.
The place where "Mihindu Maha Rahathan Wahanse" (Mihindu Thero) delivered the first Dhamma to King Devanam piyatissa) and where Buddhism was started.

Like many Sri Lankan Buddhist temples and monuments, there are many steep steps to reach the top and the temple that was built on the site of the first Sri Lankan king to be converted to Buddhism. There are some seriously steep and narrow steps if you want to get to a rock top view point where, if you get there, you are fully exposed to the heat of the sun. Frankly, the views on the way up and from the temple are more than adequate. You can reduce the total number of steps to climb by driving to a car park along Old Road. There are a number of Dagobas caves, rock carvings (including a lion claimed to be the best rock animal carving in the country) and ruined Monk's refectory and relic house to be viewed. The latter includes two inscribed stone slabs dating to the tenth century laying down the rules of the relic house and the conduct of the Monks looking after it.
Much better value than the Anuradnapura site, take some socks if you don't want to burn your feet walking barefoot, knees need to be covered too, plus watch out for those cheeky monkeys.

You have to climb lots of steps but could make many stopps and discover the ruins along the way. From the top you have a wonderful view. If you go late afternoon it's not so hot anymore and you could see the sunset.
If you like walking up the hill this is the place you should go. Lovely place very green and lot of rocks. In the season there are so many people. This place is must go in Anuradhapura!

Park in the hillside car park to save a few hundred steps. Guides accosted us immediately and we negotiated to pay what we thought it was worth at the end. Our guide did explain some of the history and interesting details about the ruins which enhanced the visit. We found visiting late afternoon into the sunset was cooler, in April. There are easy stone steps to the Temple area and a place to leave shoes as you enter the sacred area to walk up stairs to the stupa,  stone slab steps to the Buddha statute and handrailed stair to the viewpoint. We stayed for the sunset and were rewarded with good view over the countryside, our guide leaving us there in peace. We paid him the going rate he requested as we thought it worth it.

A stupa lies on top of a hill. If you are the brave soul climb all of the 1840 stairs or you can start at the trek from the car park and climb just 300 steps (cheating) You have to buy tickets there charges are 500 lkr. You have to leave your shoes at the counter. Carry socks because the walk has sand particles which pierce your feet. There is a rock which gives views but during sunset it is full of people. We avoided that and instead sat next to the stupa. The buddha statue is beautiful. Worth a visit.
You must remove your shoes and socks!  In very hot weather, the shoes of your feet will fry, but it is well worth the effort and discomfort!  Bite the bullet and go!

This place is just down the road from Anuradhapura and offers a pleasant change - especially it he evening. The site has some very old ruins from the first Buddhist monks in Sri Lanka but is also an active temple. The hilltop setting is marvellous and affords great views of the surrounding countryside and the ancient city stupas. Go around 1600 when it is cooler to walk up the steps and you can watch the sunset. A guide is useful to explain the intriguing water features and workings of the original monastery.

If you wish to visit in Anuradhapura,Don't miss it..It's few Km far from Anuradhapura town but there are so many busses you could catch.You can see so many Ancient ruins there Which is more than 2500 years old.

If you really want to taste the real Sri Lankan religious atmosphere you must go in Mihintale, speak with the people, climb the Rock and take 5 minutes to appreciate the superb view of nature, temple and Buddha statue. When we went there where only other 5 tourists. Price for foreigners is 500 rupee. Small tips to enjoy the visit : 1) bring socks because you cannot enter the site with shoes and the ground is burning; 2) also bring gym gloves to climb the rock using hand rail because they are made of iron and are also burning under the sun. 3) Best time to go is at the sunset.

We visited this as part of a tour of Anuradhapura - more steps and more bare feet of course!!  Shoes only removed at the top of the steps, after which the ground is sandy and comfortable to walk on.  We didn't climb to to the top of mountain though as it was near midday and just too hot. Mihintale felt more atmospheric as it was a little out of the way, not as busy as some of the other sights and the story of the king learning of Buddhism here brought it to life. Well worth a visit.

A most valuable place for Buddhists all over the world, but mostly for Sri-Lankans, as The great religion of Buddhism was brought from India to this hill. There is a lot of history attached to this place, so a guide or a guide book is very essential. There are lots of steps to climb, so if u go before the sun is too strong it will be much easier. Be appropriately dressed as a mark of respect to Buddhism. Well worth a visit.

Some nice views from the top, its worth going, although the tourist only 500 rupee entrance fee seems a bit steep compared to some other places. Climb the rock and go up the Buddha, you'll get a better view of the degoba from these anyway, which is just a pile of white stone, nothing particularly interesting to see up close. Go early if you don't want to sweat buckets :)

Awesome view if you have energy to climb up and down stairs.. Is a beautiful small places where you can walk around and enjoy the culture and the view from the top! A must go because it was a very zen moment to look at wonderful scenery !

Great place to visit. I enjoyed and it was nice to see it. Go in the morning or in the end of afternoon because of the heat. Bring a pair of socks with you. The floor can be really hot in some area. If you've the time go as well on the top of the mountain next to the temple. Beautiful view
Mihinthale, An ancient place to visit and it is small mountain we can see all over the anuradhapura.

Another climb up flights of worn steps without shoes! In the heat we were hopping about on the hot stones, although the Sri Lankans didn't seem bothered by it. Wonderful views at the top, though you can't go inside the dagoba.

This place is a must see. You have to climb some stairs, but once you are up there, you can see a big Buddha, a big dagoba and there is also a rock to climb which gives you a great view of the surroundings. Visit this place a the end of the afternoon, so you are in time for the sunset.

Mihinitale is a holly place with lot of vatieties. I wouldrecommendeveningis the best time to visit this place, top view is breathtaking, Speciallythe sunset. Don't miss out this place if you'replanning to visit AnuradhaPura  !!

For 500 LKR you can wander around on 582 acres. There is several beautiful places - several with a spectacular view of the surroundings. At this location, an old mango Forrest, King Devenampiyathissa met Arahath Mahinda Thero, a Buddhist enlightened monk from India. The monk introduced buddhism to the king and told him to stop hunting the animals that roam the forrest. The king was only there to administrate the earth. The king embraced Buddhism and introduced it to his kingdom. From that day Sri Lanka has been a country of Buddhists.

Being a few km outside of Anuradhapura a lot of tourists miss this site. If at all possible, do not make the same mistake. It is quite simply the most breathtaking historic religious site we visited in our two week stay in Sri Lanka. There is a board at the bottom of the hill very helpfully stating there are 1800 steps. This may be true in a manner of speaking, but please do not be put off - it is not necessary to do anywhere near that many. From the car park there is a short sloping road up to the ticket office level, and then there are about 200 steps (mostly shaded) to the 'Take your shoes off' cabin (as with every temple in SL take thick socks to avoid burnt feet and constantly dodging sharp stones). From there it's only about 30 more to the central stupa area. This area is shady and relaxing. From this level you can climb to a stunning white buddha (probably only about 50 steps but as they are carved into the rock some are a bit awkward so take care - there is a handrail however). You could also climb from the central area up to the big stupa, that's about another 200 steps (shaded) but definitely worth it for the stunning views and the cool breeze! There are also options from the central area to climb up to sunset rock (we didn't bother, it looked crowded and was nowhere near sunset - the views can't be all that different from the big stupa) and down to some kind of cave art - we got halfway down and gave up as we couldn't face climbing all the way back up afterwards! Please note if you are THAT kind of tourist, there are no sweetie shops, hot dog stands or kiddies playparks here. It is a historical religious site. If you want those things, stay at home. Otherwise, if you can handle the steps (which as stated above are not as numerous as claimed) this place is magical and worth a few hours of anyone's time. Do take your socks and some water though.

If you're not afraid of climbing a few steps, then you'll be rewarded not only with a wonderful view, but also a temple that is worth visiting. Tourist pay 500 LKR that is worth it. Also visit nearby black pond and monk meditation quarters under rocks in a lush forest!

As guidance this place is where the Buddhism introduce to Sri Lanka. According to historical records monk mahinda has been arrived to this place and met King Devanampiyathissa and introduced Buddhism. The king has been confidence d with Buddhism  and built a big monastery in this place and offered to the monks to live and spread Buddhism in the country. This place is so interesting to visit anyone there is a historical value in every parts.

We went here after visiting the ruins of Anhuradpura and this is by far the better out of the two. Nice and quiet. There are several sections to see with great views of the surrounding area. Only thing to worry about is walking on the hot stone, which can be quite uncomfortable with the midday sun!

Beautiful sight. Mihintale is a short ride from Anuradhapura It is a little bit a strenuous walk up the mountain but not too difficult. On top there are actually three peaks with each its sight. One has a stupa the other a beautiful statue. The last one and the hardest to reach has the most beautiful view and in between these peaks there is the shrine for the buddha's which marks the place where the buddhism came to Sri lanka.

We visited after 4 pm. It was crowded but not too bad, and the heat was not too bad. As mentioned by many reviewers, the rock climb is steep but not too strenuous. You are competing for a foot hold on the path and a hand hold on the rails and doing it barefoot. Still, it was well worth the climb. The climbs to the Buddha figure and the Dagoba on either side of the rock are through regular stairs and are easy. The views from the Dagoba are magnificent. If you are going during the day wear socks as the stone and sand paths come become unbearably hot to walk on.

The walk up is not strenuous at all to the base area. From there you have three places you can walk up to; the stuppa, the giant Buddha statue and the very tall rock viewpoint area. If you go mid day the ground on your bare feet is hot,hot,hot.  Bare feet are required from near the entrance. The views are beautiful.
This is a beautiful sight. Nice view from the top, Buddha, Dagoba, Devotees. Very interesting and a great workout! 500rps fee is well worth it.

I can't really add to what FearfulFlyer & DavidH has already said. It's a bit of climb (but quite exciting!) to the cliff top viewpoint where views are spectacular. You can also climb up steps to beautiful white stupa and up to a seated Buddha. The monkeys were cute as you like and no bother (ie they didn't try to steal things, they just looked endearing).

This climb starts off as fairly easy until you reach the first plateau.  You then have three choices for further climbs. On the advice of our guide, I chose the difficult rock climb first. To get up to the rock you need to navigate up a staircase built into the stone, with a handrail available in the difficult spots. It's quite steep and some of the carved steps are only an inch or two deep, so you need to take it slowly and surely.  Once you reach the top and make it to the narrow platform area the views are spectacular. Going down can be a bit problematic if you are competing for space for those ascending.  It's advisable to hold the handrail at all times but sometimes this isn't possible.  Even if you are wearing walking shoes it can be a bit slippy.  Our guide said barefoot was best but then the rock can get very hot in the sun.  It's one of those descents where you are glad to reach the bottom. After that it's easy to ascend to the temple area using conventional steps. Here the views are almost as good and there is no difficulty to overcome. All in all this is a good complex with spectacular views from the highest spots.

Mihintale was by far the most beautiful part of my trip to Anuradhapura. The views are spectacular and you can sit and stare out for hours if you wanted. I was so lucky with the weather so stayed for about two and a half hours. I took the easy way up with a tuktuk halfway then climbed the last part because of time. There are monks and Buddhists all around and you feel like you're in a very spiritual place. There is a large Buddha statue, a huge stupa and another viewpoint you can climb up to. Don't miss this site and try to go around sunset because the views are spectacular!
A lovely reasonably quiet  location at this rocky outcrop with great views - it is well worth the moderate climb.

We visited this place on poya day, but is was not to busy. We took bicycles from Anuradhapura, which is about 12/14 km along a busy road, so keep left, and move on the side when a bus comes. The steps are shaded by beautiful trees. Keep your eyes on the monkeys, they can be a bit too naughty. Before you reach the top, there is a shed with drinks, tea. Before you enter, you can leave your shoes /slippers at a dropoff point. On top there are 3 additional climbs. The rock can be a bit scarry if you don't like heights. On sunny days the rock gets really hot (for bare feet), but the views are amazing!!! 360 panorama. Altogether nice activity for 2-4 hours.

We are a travel agency in Sri Lanka, and has been to many tourist destinations in Sri Lanka. But the view from the top of this small mountainous mihintale temple is simply stunning. Also this site's entrance fees are also comparatively lower than most of the other sites in the country. So, we recommend this temple to every traveler! ,don't miss it if you are visiting Anuradhapura.

This ancient site, the cradle of Sri Lankan Buddhism, is a lovely place to visit.  It isn't far from the better known site of Anuradhapura, and is well worth visiting as well.  It may not be World Heritage listed, but it is nice and nicer than many places that are. There are a lot of steps leading up to the site - almost 2000 in all.  However if you have transport, you can be driven up to quite near the top and only climb a few of them.  I am unfit and found it perfectly fine climbing from there, I suspect the full climb would be all right too if you started early and took it at a gentle pace. The site consists of several interesting buildings; the ruins of a monastery, two pagodas, a small museum, and a giant sitting Buddha.  There is also a steep rocky viewpoint which can be climbed if you don't mind a bit of a scramble.  The views are wonderful, looking out over the countryside. The area has great religious significance for Buddhists as it is believed to be the site where the first Buddhist king of Sri Lanka was converted to the religion by a group of monks.  The spot where he met the monks is marked by a tree and a nearby very small museum. As it is a religious site, you need to remove your shoes before the final set of steps and leave them with the shoe attendants.  You may keep your socks on, which is a good idea as the ground gets hot here in the open sun.  You should also ensure your shoulders and legs to below the knee are covered.  Hats also need to be removed.  There is limited shade at the top so be sure to where plenty of suncream or take a scarf (which is permitted). I'd highly recommend this site for a visit as it is beautiful and interesting.  It would not be a good place to visit in the rain though as the climb to the top of the viewpoint would be dangerous in wet conditions I think, and the views may not be so good.  It's also quite exposed.  I think children would like it, as there's lots to see.  It's also less crowded than many of the sites I visited in the region and has a peaceful feeling even when there are plenty of people around.
We took the wimps route and got our driver to take us as far as possible rather than the steep climb up the steps. Still it was well worth the visit stunning views and very atmospheric.

Hi Travellers, If you are in Anuradhapura and planning for a nice place to visit, Mihintale is a better place to spend time. How to reach there:- Most of the hotel hosts will recommend to hire a tuk tuk driver to reach mihintale which is about 8km from Anuradhapura. You can take bus from Old Anuradhapura and reach mihintale in about half an hour. What to expect:- A typical worship place occupied by buddhist monks during early centuries What you see:- A picturesque landscape of Srilankan country side from the observation peak. View of Buddha and the Dagoba from the peak is also worth the climb, You will be welcomed by the blossoming trees along the climb which makes your climb easier. Note:- You have entrance fee.

We hadn't researched this place before our guide took us there one afternoon so we had  no expectations. But just just the sight of the stairs surrounded by frangipani trees in full blossom make this site a must to visit. It was absolutely beautiful. From there on it's 1800 steps up to the temple and to see beautiful views of the Sri Lankan landscape. The steps are not hard to climb, it will take you ten to twenty minutes. As we went in the afternoon the sundown bathed the whole area in marvelous lights. The icing on the cake was to climb up the viewpoint area on the pointy rock formation. The climb is slightly tough as there are no railings in some places and it's pretty steep, but it's well worth it as the view from the top is just amazing. The minor adrenaline rush from climbing up also gives the experience that little extra. To be honest the place was my best experience so far in Sri Lanka after being here two weeks so far and after being to both Lion rock and Adams peak which both can be compared to this site. A must do on your visit to Sri Lanka.

Well worth seeing. try and visit in the evening as it's much cooler and you will get to see the sunset. No need for one of the self appointed guides as it is easy to find you way around. the view from the top is magnificent.

Go to mihintale because the ambiance and view at the temple is really Great. You can get there from anuradhapura. Make sure the tuctuc driver wait for you. It Costs us about 1400 roepies to get there from anuradhapura.
This is a very charming place to visit. Well preserved, and feel good after seeing what we have and to be saved for generations.

Don't be spooked by the advertised 1800 steps! I think they counted ALL of the steps on the entire mountain. It's more likely that you take approx. 100 to the first platform. On top you can choose 3 different viewing platforms (max. 200 steps each): Buddha, the stupa and a rock. Very nice views of the surroundings. Monkeys in the car park. The usual attire: ladies,  cover your knees and shoulders, and bring socks if you have sensitive soles (as in all temples,  you need to take off your shoes).
A Stupak, a Buddha and a rock view await you after the long climb, and somehow it seems worth it. Do it.

A little way from the far busier and noisier city of Anuradhapura, the great stupa at Mihintale makes for a marvellous visit.  It's a long but easy climb up the mostly stairs to the base of the stupa, while the energetic can enjoy some diversions to subsidiary points of interest on the way.  Worth starting the jaunt early in the morning, cooler and ahead of the crowds.  As the place where Buddhism arrived in Sri Lanka, it has a special resonance and 'feels' spiritual in an undefinable way.  At the end of the day there are very friendly and nice stalls for refreshments.
A bit of climbing is required to reach the top but it's worth it, the views are great. At the same time, we discover an important spot for Buddhism and met loads of monkeys on the way!
Would definitely recommend coming here as well as Anaradhupura.  We particularly liked the black water pond(?) and the rocks.  Very calm place.

Mihintale is one of the most amazing places I have ever been. The walk is pleasant and the climb a little tough but when you get to the top of that rock it is just breathtaking. My 14 year old said it was the highlight of his trip. It was very peaceful and my wife found it a great spot to meditate.
Very simple, but strongly respected holly place. Lots of ancient monuments and a stream of local followers of the budhism. Nice to see the way people respect their history and culture!
We visited during a spectacular tropical storm so unfortunately did not get to fully appreciate the views which must be wonderful. Worth a visit anyway

Even though I am a Sri Lankan this was my first visit to Mihintale. First thing that striked me was the immense natural beauty of the temple and the surrounding area. The rock area has plenty of climbing choices and different views of the Dagoba and Lord Buddha. The steps are surrounded by Temple Trees which I assume on blooming days would be mesmerising. Unfortunately, the day we went was a rainy day. Worth a visit if you are in the cultural triangle of Sri Lanka.

over 1500 steps to the main point very beautiful infrastructure Indian monk has been to this point by spiritual power and introduce Buddhism to king Devanam Piyatissa when he was chasing a deer for hunt
Do not miss this beautiful place .great views and day trip for the family. Stop at the black pond to rest and refresh
This is a religious place of Buddhists. Very beautiful place. You can see great views in the peak of the rock.

Like 15 km from Anuradhnapure you can easily get there by Tuktuk. There is an entrance fee of around 1000 rps per person (tourist price) and you pay to leave your shoes half the way, before entering the sacred area. You have to climb lots of steps so either do it in the early morning or late afternoon, then you can see also sunset. On the top you have several locations where you can stop by. We were upstairs on a sunday so it was quite crowded with local people. For us it was just another temple, I mean if you're not sophisticated in buddhism. However you have a nice view from the top.
Lots of stairs around 500 but the view it is worth the rise. Very nice statues and huge panorama . Do it

Be blessed by visiting the cradle of Buddhism in Sri Lanka. Avoid poya days and public holidays as its going to be packed with local travelers. Cheap accommodation & F&B available in the Mihintale Junction. Don't miss visiting the ancient Kaludiya Pokuna which is just 1 km towards Dambulla (no entrance fees).

This place is nice trying compared to Anuradhapura and Polonnaruwa Sacred cities which are not worth the money (25-30 USD per person and more ruins than anything to see with what you can identify the Buddhism religion). Nice view over the country at sunset but watch the monkeys as they can be sneaky. Many stairs to climb!

We arrived late-ish in the afternoon with not too much expectation having not ressearched the area prior to our arrival. It was such an amazing place, the story was so interesting and there was barely any other tourist there. We stayed until sunset and it is the best view point to do so in the area,. On a clear day you can see the reflection of the sun in the lakes and the temples light up around you. The enty price is now 500Rs (not 400Rs like stated in the Lonely Planet) and it is well worth it. I definitively recommend it, avoid midday though as it might get very hot.

Before getting there we feel Mahintale may be just a place where stupa was. But when Matheesha tour brought us up there. We found amazingly very good place to visit. There were three peak of hill top.  A big white buddha statue, a big pagoda, and a adventurous highest peak to creep up. This last peak need a walking stick with rubber tip or tip finger rubber glove to ease and safe. The tour told us to prepare.

The view is beautiful and the early time makes it a very peaceful place to watch the sun rise. There is a bit of a climb to the viewpoint but it is not long. The temple itself was subdued and it was a real experience hearing the morning worship. We had a guide who was very knowledgeable about Buddhism and gave us information about the stupah and what was visible from the viewpoint.
we climbed the top , it has amazing views and its a very religious place so you will have to wear white if you go here.

Believed by Sri Lankans to be the site  the Buddhist monk Mahinda preached the Dharma to King Devanampiyatissa. There's an lot to see in the site and a hard climb to all of them including Aradhana Gala, where the Arahant Mahinda landed from India and the cave where Mahinda slept etc. As a history buff, I just had to visit this site. I don't know if the stories are true, but it's a nice idea to be where history was made. The views from Aradhana Gala are just stunning. 3 different views of the Stupa, Buddha or the town are possible. Magic.

The site offers a range of attractions - beautiful Buddha in white, a large and small stupa and a very slipper rock to climb from which you may take breathtaking district views.  On the way up some interesting ruins of what would've have been a monastery and some stone tablets explaining the roles and duties of monks - if you can read Sinhalese in the original script.
I enjoyed this more than the sacred city. The views are stunning and the man in the shop/cafe half way up is lovely. Go early and avoid midday Sun, it is roasting!!

Arrived in Anurahdapura after lunch and caught a tuk tuk to Mihintale for the afternoon. Such a spectacular place with an amazing history. We watched the sun set over the breath taking landscape from the dagoba whilst traditional drums played creating a serene atmosphere. We could have used another hour or so to explore more of the area but definitely a great way to spend the afternoon.
Mihinthale is a small mountain just 12 km away from Hotel Randiya. I had a nice view of Sunset. You can take a bus going via Mihinthale from Bus Halt nearby.

An incredable place! Wechose to go here instead of the ruins and I'm so pleased we did, a fabulous place,great views and terrific buda statue. It was only 500 rupees (2.50) which was incredable value.
